{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{infobox website | name = TV Converter Box Coupon Program | logo = [[Image:US-DTVConverterBoxCouponProgram-Logo.svg|200px]] | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{url|https://web.archive.org/web/20091104004349/https://www.dtv2009.gov/|www.DTV2009.gov}} | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 8,644,849 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/dtv2009.gov |title= Dtv2009.gov Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref> | commercial = No | type = U.S. federal government | language = English, [[Spanish language|Spanish]], and portion of other languages. | registration = | owner = [[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]] | launch date = January 2008 | current status = Defunct | revenue = }}
A '''coupon-eligible converter box''' ('''CECB''') was a [[digital television adapter]] that met eligibility specifications for [[subsidy]] "coupons" from the [[United States government]]. The subsidy program was enacted to provide [[terrestial television|over-the-air]] television viewers with an affordable way to continue receiving free [[digital terrestrial television|digital over-the-air television]] services after the nation's television service [[DTV transition in the United States|transitioned to digital transmission]] and [[analog shutdown|analog transmissions ceased]]. The specification was developed by the [[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]] (NTIA), with input from the broadcast and [[consumer electronics]] industries as well as [[public interest]] groups.
== History ==
=== Early proposals === In March 2005, [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|United States House Commerce Committee]] chairman [[Joe Barton]] of Texas said he would introduce a bill requiring the transition to digital television "sometime in the spring", saying he wanted analog broadcasting to end on December 31, 2006. Included in his plan was a $400–$500 million subsidy for converter boxes, which were expected to cost $50 each. The subsidies were intended only for people who could not afford a [[Multichannel Video Programming Distributor|pay service]] such as cable or satellite television. Each home would receive a rebate coupon for one box, which could be mailed to the [[United States Treasury]] for redemption. Barton estimated that 8 to 10 million converters would be needed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/156484-Barton_Targets_DTV_Bill_for_Spring.php |title=Barton Targets DTV Bill for Spring |work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |first=Bill |last=McConnell |date=March 15, 2005 |accessdate=August 12, 2009}}</ref>
=== Digital Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005 === The United States [[Digital Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005]], part of the [[Deficit Reduction Act of 2005]], required that the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) direct all full-power television stations to cease [[analog TV]] broadcasting before midnight on February 17, 2009. (This deadline later changed to June 12.) Recognizing that consumers might wish to continue receiving broadcast programming over-the-air using analog-only televisions, the Act authorized the NTIA to create a digital-to-analog converter box assistance program. [[Consumer education]] plans for the subsidy program were targeted to [[low-income]], [[elderly]], [[disabled]], [[inner city]], immigrant, and rural Americans, because these groups were more likely to use an antenna instead of [[cable television|cable]] or satellite television.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-08-1040 | accessdate =June 26, 2011 | title = Digital Television Transition: Implementation of the Converter Box Subsidy Program Is Under Way, but Preparedness to Manage an Increase in Subsidy Demand Is Unclear | work = GAO | publisher = United States Government Accountability Office | date = September 16, 2008 | id = GAO-08-1040 }}</ref> The Act also established a new [[United States Department of the Treasury|Treasury]] fund, known as the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Fund. It directed the FCC to deposit the receipts from the [[spectrum auction]] of the returned analog television frequencies into the fund.
The Act directed the NTIA to implement and administer a program through which eligible US households could obtain a maximum of two "coupons" (actually [[payment]] [[voucher]]s) of $40 each, to be applied towards the purchase of a digital-to-analog converter box. The Act defines the term ''converter box'' to mean "a stand-alone device that does not contain features or functions except those necessary to enable a consumer to convert any channel broadcast in the digital television service into a format that the consumer can display on television receivers designed to receive and display signals only in the analog television service, but may also include a [[remote control]] device." The Act, however, did not define "eligible household".<ref>{{cite report|url=http://www.techpolicyinstitute.org/files/the_dtv_coupon_program.pdf |title=The DTV Coupon Program: A Boon to Retailers, not Consumers |last=Wallsten |first=Scott |date=September 15, 2008 |publisher=Technology Policy Institute |location=Washington, DC |accessdate=June 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728083308/http://techpolicyinstitute.org/files/the_dtv_coupon_program.pdf |archivedate=July 28, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>
As of April 2006, 20 million people (some with more than one set) received only over-the-air TV. When the number of people subscribing to [[Multichannel Video Programming Distributor|cable or satellite]] who also had TVs that only used an antenna, an estimated 70 million TVs would need upgrading.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/103959-Old_TVs_Steal_Show_at_NAB.php |title=Old TVs Steal Show at NAB |work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |first=Glen |last=Dickson |date=April 30, 2006 |accessdate=August 12, 2009}}</ref>
=== Implementing the program === In 2006, the NTIA let people see its plan for distributing coupons and comment on it. The plan prohibited people with cable or satellite service from requesting coupons. In order to get two coupons, consumers had to state that they had two television sets. In an effort to limit misconduct, coupon requests would be only be taken between January 1, 2008 and March 31, 2009; each coupon would be valid for three months. The consumer-education program only had a budget of $5 million, so the companies participating in the transition would have to help.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/93696-Cable_Households_Won_t_Get_Converter_Subsidy.php |title=Cable Households Won't Get Converter Subsidy |work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |first=John |last=Eggerton |date=July 24, 2006 |accessdate=August 12, 2009}}</ref>
On March 12, 2007, the NTIA held a news conference to announce the standards for the converter boxes and the requirements for receiving coupons. With the standards established, manufacturing could begin and the NTIA could select a company to send out coupons.<ref>{{cite journal | first= Ira |last = Teinowitz | title = News briefs: Digital TV One Step Closer |journal = Television Week| date= March 12, 2007 | page = 4 | volume = 26 | issue = 11}}</ref>
With $1.5 billion in funding, the coupons would account for only half of the 73 million analog TVs not using a pay service, including 18 million in homes having only over-the-air TV reception. The [[United States Commerce Department|Commerce Department]] had no plans to make coupons available only to the poor.
Coupons could be requested by phone, mail, or online.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/products/2007-03-12-tv-box-coupons_N.htm|title=All in U.S. eligible for TV box coupons|work=USA Today|date=March 13, 2007|accessdate=August 6, 2009 | first=Paul | last=Davidson}}</ref> At first, anyone would be able to apply, even for those who had one or more TVs connected to cable or satellite.
The NTIA set the standards for the converter box based on what manufacturers and broadcasters wanted. [[LG Electronics]], [[Thomson SA|Thomson]], [[Samsung Group|Samsung]], and [[Jasco Products Company|Jasco]] were the first companies to announce plans to make the devices. After June 1, 2007, retailers could apply to sell converter boxes. Each would have to be in the NTIA's Central Contractor Registration database, and have been in the consumer-electronics business for at least a year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Four Suppliers Plan To Build Converter Boxes |journal=TWICE |date=March 26, 2007 |publisher=NewBay Media |location=New York, NY |url=http://www.twice.com/article/250270-Four_Suppliers_Plan_To_Build_Converter_Boxes.php |accessdate=June 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406112453/http://www.twice.com/article/250270-Four_Suppliers_Plan_To_Build_Converter_Boxes.php |archivedate=April 6, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref>
[[Image:FCC DTV Coupon Card.png|right|thumb|275px|An example of the NTIA converter box $40 subsidy "coupon", which is in the form of a [[ATM card|bank card]] that can only be used as payment for a converter box purchase.]] To implement the coupon program, the Act authorized NTIA to use up to $990 million from the fund, including $100 million for program administration. Those funds supported an initial "non-contingent" program that was available to all requesting households. NTIA was also authorized to spend up to $1.5 billion for the program (including $160 million for administration) if the initial $990 million were insufficient to fulfill the non-contingent coupon requests. In that case, a "contingent" fund would be available for US households not serviced by cable or satellite.<ref name=ntiafinalrule>{{cite report | url = http://www.ntia.doc.gov/ntiahome/frnotices/2007/DTVFinalRule_2a.htm | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090603214653/http://www.ntia.doc.gov/ntiahome/frnotices/2007/DTVFinalRule_2a.htm | archivedate = June 3, 2009 | title = Rules to Implement and Administer a Coupon Program for Digital-to-Analog Converter Boxes | docket = 0612242667-7051-01 | author = National Telecommunications and Information Administration | publisher = United States Department of Commerce }}</ref> If the funds were insufficient, the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the [[United States Senate|Senate]] would be notified.
An initial funding of $990 million was expected to allow all US households an opportunity to apply for the coupons, which expired 90 days after they were mailed. After that money was used up, $510 million in additional funds was available to households that stated they did not already subscribe to cable or satellite television services. Neither allotment had a [[means test]].<ref name=ntiafinalrule/>
The NTIA planned to start processing coupon requests a year before the original transition date of February 17, 2009; 2.4 million people had applied for 4.7 million coupons, out of an estimated 13 million homes that still received television with an antenna.<ref name=ready>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/112503-Ready_or_Not_Here_Comes_DTV.php|title=Ready or Not, Here Comes DTV|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=February 18, 2008|accessdate=September 10, 2009}}</ref>
By the end of 2008, the ''New York Times'' said "about 40 million coupons have been requested, but to date 16 million have been redeemed, compared with an estimated 35 million televisions that will lose a signal."<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/22/technology/22digital.html | title = In Move to Digital TV, Confusion Is in the Air | last = Taub | first = Eric A. | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York | accessdate =June 26, 2011 | publisher = The New York Times Company | date=December 22, 2008}}</ref> Institutions, such as [[retirement home]]s, were initially excluded from the program; while this was partially remedied (to allow one coupon per retirement-home resident),{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} prisons,<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26548827 |title=Prisons scramble to make digital TV switch|first =Jim |last=Davenport|work=MSNBC|date=September 4, 2008|accessdate=June 26, 2011}}</ref> homeless shelters<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-coverside1-2009mar01,0,1094570.story |title=Digital TV may bypass skid row|first=Nathan|last= Olivarez-Giles|newspaper= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date= March 1, 2009|accessdate=June 26, 2011|location = Los Angeles}}</ref> and residential hotels remained disqualified from the coupon program.
On January 4, 2009, the NTIA began placing coupon requests on a [[wikt:waiting list|waiting list]] after the program reached its maximum allowed funding. Only after unredeemed coupons expire could new requests be fulfilled.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hart|first=Kim|title=TV Converter Program Runs Out of Funding|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/01/06/ST2009010600089.html|work=The Washington Post|page=D01|date=January 6, 2008|accessdate=January 6, 2008}}</ref> By January 7, NTIA's waiting list included just under a million requested coupons. A week later, the list had grown to two million coupons.<ref name="NTIA stats">http://www.dtv2009.gov/Stats.aspx {{Dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
On January 7, both [[Consumers Union]] and Representative [[Ed Markey]] of Massachusetts (who headed the [[U.S. House]] [[Energy and Commerce Committee]]’s [[Telecommunication|telecom]] subcommittee) advocated that the February 17, 2009 analog shutoff date be postponed, due to the lack of coupons and NTIA's inability to handle the expected public enquiries.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.tvweek.com/news/2009/01/key_congressman_floats_dtvswit.php |title=Key Congressman Floats DTV-Switch Delay |last=Teinowitz |first=Ira |date=January 7, 2009 |journal=TVWeek |publisher=Crain Communications |accessdate=June 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308225026/http://www.tvweek.com/news/2009/01/key_congressman_floats_dtvswit.php |archivedate=March 8, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref> On January 8, [[Presidential transition of Barack Obama|President-Elect Barack Obama's transition team]] contacted key legislators to express support for a delay, largely because of problems funding coupons for converters.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/la-fi-dtv9-2009jan09,0,1586472.story | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20090118214941/http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/la-fi-dtv9-2009jan09,0,1586472.story | archivedate = January 18, 2009 | title = All-digital TV? Please stand by | last = Puzzanghera | first = Jim | last2 = Parsons | first2 = Christi | date = January 9, 2009 | agency = Los Angeles Times | location = Chicago | work=Chicago Tribune}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/08/AR2009010802586.html | title = Obama Urges Delay In Digital TV Switch|first= Kim|last= Hart|newspaper= The Washington Post |date= January 9, 2009| accessdate =June 26, 2011 | location = Washington, DC | page = D01}}</ref> The delay passed early in February (see [[#DTV Delay Act|below]]).
== Specifications == The NTIA Specification is arranged in three categories, describing required, permitted, and disqualifying features.
=== Absolute requirements === [[Image:Converterbox.JPG|thumb|right|A digital TV converter box]] These features were absolutely required, but varied in the way they are provided by the box.
Coupon-eligible converter boxes had to convert all [[ATSC Standards#Resolution|ATSC (digital) formats]] to the traditional [[NTSC]] analog system used by analog US television sets. The box must output signals both as a [[radio frequency]] output (compatible with a television's antenna input), as well as [[composite video]] and stereo audio outputs. It must include a remote control, and be compatible with [[universal remote]]s.
The units had to support both a [[4:3]] center [[Cropping (image)|crop]] of a [[16:9]] transmitted image, and a [[letterbox]] rendition of a [[16:9]] transmitted image. The video outputs had to produce video at an [[ITU-R]] BT.500-11 [[video quality|quality scale]] of Grade 4 or higher. Various technical performance parameters for the digital tuner were also specified.
The boxes must decode [[Emergency Alert System]] (EAS) messages, [[Closed Captioning]] data, and [[TV Parental Guidelines|Parental Control]] ([[V-Chip]]) descriptors. They must decode the [[Program and System Information Protocol]] (PSIP) data from the digital transmission, and use it to provide the user with tuned channel and program information.
CECBs must consume no more than an average of 2 watts of [[Standby power|power when not in use]] (no video or audio display). They must provide an automatic power-down option that can put the unit in standby mode when it has not received any commands for a while.
=== Optional features === Manufacturers could self-certify compliance with these requirements, but had to provide test results and two units to the NTIA for ''ad hoc'' testing. The FCC could also test converter boxes at the NTIA's request. Among the optional features permitted, but not required, were the following:
* Support for a [[smart antenna]], through the use of the [[CEA-909]] Antenna Control Interface. The manufacturer could optionally provide a promotional package discount for the combination of a smart antenna and a CECB. * [[Multichannel television sound]] (BTSC) stereo at the RF output. * [[S-Video]] output. * [[Analog passthrough]], as needed for [[LPTV]], [[broadcast translator]], and foreign signal reception. * [[Electronic program guide]] * [[patch (computing)|Software updates]]. * Support for the [[Television content rating systems#Canadian ratings|Canadian television ratings]] system, allowing the manufacturer to sell the same device in Canada. * Support for secondary audio channels, such as foreign languages or [[Descriptive Video Service]].<ref>{{Citation|url = http://www.fcc.gov/cgb/consumerfacts/dtvvideodescription.pdf | format = PDF | title = Video Descriptions and the Digital Television Transition | series = FCC Consumer Advisory | author = Consumer & Governmental Affairs Bureau | publisher = Federal Communications Commission | location = Washington, DC | accessdate =June 26, 2011 }}</ref>
While an outdoor antenna is required for adequate digital reception in most locations beyond {{convert|10|–|25|mi|km|0}} from [[TV transmitter]]s, and [[smart antenna]] interfaces were an optionally permitted feature of coupon-eligible converter boxes,<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.dtv.gov/outreach_article_antennas.html | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100527171925/http://www.dtv.gov/outreach_article_antennas.html | archivedate = May 27, 2010 | title = Outreach Toolkit—Article: DTV and Antenna | work = DTV.gov | publisher = Federal Communications Commission | location = Washington, DC }}</ref> there were no subsidies for antennas. Although manufacturers could sell a converter/smart-antenna bundle, they were required to also offer the converter by itself to consumers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcc.gov/cgb/consumerfacts/dtvantennas.html |title = Antennas and Digital Television | work = FCC.gov | publisher = Federal Communications Commission | author = Consumer and Government Affairs Bureau | accessdate =June 26, 2011}}</ref>
DTV converter boxes could earn a [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] [[Energy Star]] label if they consume no more than eight watts of electricity while operating, no more than one watt while in [[standby mode]], and if they automatically power-down after four hours of inactivity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=dta.pr_dta |title=EPA: energystar.gov |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205045254/http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=dta.pr_dta |archivedate=December 5, 2008 }}</ref>
=== Disqualifying features === Some features disqualified a converter box from coupon eligibility, such as [[High-definition television|high-definition]] video output and built-in [[digital video recorder|DVR]] functionality. [[Digital cable]] and [[direct broadcast satellite|satellite]] [[set-top box]]es that incorporate a digital tuner were also disqualified.
Certain output features were prohibited from coupon-eligible devices: [[component video]], [[Video Graphics Array|VGA]], [[RGB color model|RGB]], [[Digital Visual Interface|DVI]], [[High-Definition Multimedia Interface|HDMI]], [[Universal Serial Bus|USB]] video, IEEE-1394/iLink/[[Firewire]] video, [[Ethernet]] video, and IEEE-802.11/[[WiFi]] video outputs.<ref name=ntiafinalrule/>
=== Limitations === Coupon-eligible converter boxes only tune to one channel at a time, as they only contain one digital tuner and no analog tuner. In order to watch one channel while recording another, one must have two such converter boxes, unless the recording device has its own digital TV tuner.
Most [[Videocassette recorder|video recorders]] were also unable to change channels under control of built-in [[timer]]s when using a converter, as channel selection was then handled by the converter.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.mercurynews.com/businessheadlines/ci_11692884 | title = With shift to digital TV, how long can VCRs stay afloat? | first = Troy | last = Wolverton | newspaper = San José Mercury News | location = San Jose, CA | date = February 16, 2009 | archiveurl = http://benton.org/node/22185 | archivedate = February 17, 2009 }}</ref> Some converter boxes have a programmable timer, which the user could program to match the recording schedule of their VCR. Then, the converter's tuner will change to the appropriate channel at the time the VCR needs to record. This requires a separate box for the VCR, or the viewer will have to watch what is being recorded. Another, less common option is an "[[IR blaster]]", which a recorder can use to control an external tuner, like a cable set-top box or converter box. However, older devices with IR blasters may not be fully compatible with [[digital subchannel]]s; the converter box may require the use of a [-] or [.] button to specify the subchannel, which the pre-digital recorder may not know how to transmit. Some older [[TiVo]] brand digital recorders received software updates specifically to control digital converter boxes via the TiVo's included IR blaster.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://support.tivo.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/310 | title = Which digital converter boxes for antenna are compatible with my TiVo DVR? | publisher = TiVo | accessdate = June 26, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140917105103/http://support.tivo.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/310 | archivedate = September 17, 2014 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Small battery-operated portable televisions, while valuable in time of [[disaster]], are generally poorly suited to digital conversion. While at least one CECB (Winegard's RCDT09A) is operable from an external battery pack,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://reviews.cnet.com/tv-hdtv-tuners-receivers/winegard-rcdt09a/4505-6487_7-33280760.html | title = Winegard RCDT09A | first = Matthew | last = Moskovciak | work = CNET Reviews | date = September 30, 2008 | publisher = CBS Interactive | accessdate =June 26, 2011 }}</ref> the combination of television, converter, external antenna, and power supply limits portability.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/local/se_texans_might_have_more_time_to_prep_for_digital_switch_02-16-2009.html | title = Southeast Texans might have more time to prep for digital switch | last = Guy | first = Colin | newspaper = Beaumont Enterprise| date=February 16, 2009| location = Beaumont, TX | accessdate =June 26, 2011 | quote = Although Burlington, Iowa-based Winegard produces a battery-powered digital converter box, some viewers might find that the tiny antennas attached to portable televisions and the rabbit-ears in their living room aren't sufficient to pick up a digital signal. | publisher = Hearst Newspapers }}</ref> {{As of|2009}}, portable digital [[LCD]] [[TV set]]s cost at least $100, and could not be used while in motion at significant speeds (restoring this analog functionality would require broadcasters to transmit [[mobile TV]] via the separate [[ATSC-M/H]] standard, which would in itself require new tuners).
The inability of some boxes to add new digital channels without a full re-scan—deleting all existing channel settings—renders them unusable to viewers who rely on [[directional antenna]]s and [[antenna rotator|rotors]] to receive distant stations. Signal strength meters, where available, are awkward, typically only displaying information for channels that have already been found.<ref>[http://dtv.broadcastnewsroom.com/articles/viewarticle.jsp?id=428905 DTV Broadcast Newsroom] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122102615/http://dtv.broadcastnewsroom.com/articles/viewarticle.jsp?id=428905 |date=January 22, 2009 }}</ref> This is problematic, as digital signals are most often transmitted on higher frequencies or with far less power than their analog counterparts,<ref>{{cite report | url = http://www.dtvanswers.com/webcasts/060408_FinalSlides.ppt | format = PPT | title = Digital Television (DTV) Transition Campaign Overview | author = DTVAnswers.com | publisher = National Association of Broadcasters | date = June 4, 2008 | accessdate =June 26, 2011}} NAB's DTVanswers.com estimates 1,295 stations relocating to a channel different than their NTSC channel, many across bands.</ref> requiring careful antenna installation, orientation and location to avoid obstructions, fading and [[multipath interference]] problems. Where the converter fails to receive a channel, an often-cumbersome manual process is usually provided; however, this requires knowledge of which frequencies each missing station is actually transmitting on, rather than the [[virtual channel]]s each is mapped to by the ATSC protocol.
Since the NTIA did not require CECBs to output [[multichannel television sound|MTS]] stereo signals via their radio-frequency output, [[THAT Corporation]]<ref group=nb>Which licensed the now-expired patents to the [[dbx (noise reduction)|dbx noise reduction]] technology used in MTS, and still holds patents on some digital implementations of MTS</ref> noted that consumers using RF-only connections with CECBs will lose stereo TV sound.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thatcorp.com/dbxTV-DTV-transition.html | title = dbx-TV and the Digital TV Transition | publisher = THAT Corporation | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081015130126/http://www.thatcorp.com/dbxTV-DTV-transition.html | archivedate = October 15, 2008 | deadurl = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> This problem may be avoided by using the converter's [[line level]] audio outputs.
== Low-power television concerns == {{Anchor|LPTV concerns}} A year before the transition, Ron Bruno, president of the [[Community Broadcasters Association]] (CBA), said only four of 37 NTIA-certified converter boxes had analog passthrough, and none had analog tuners.<ref name=ready/>
In late March 2008, the CBA filed a [[lawsuit]] in the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia]] seeking an [[injunction]] to halt the sale and distribution of CECBs.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=90157323|title=What Will Digital Do to Low-Power TV?|first=Joel|last=Rose|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=May 3, 2008|accessdate=August 20, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://broadcastengineering.com/newsrooms/community_broadcasters_association_petitions_0328 |title=Community Broadcasters Association petitions court to order DTV converter halt |work=[[Broadcast Engineering]] |date=March 28, 2008 |accessdate=August 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204165323/http://broadcastengineering.com/newsrooms/community_broadcasters_association_petitions_0328 |archivedate=December 4, 2008 |df=mdy }}</ref> According to the CBA, the converters' lack of support for analog transmissions would harm its member stations, which include [[low-power broadcasting|low-power]] and [[class A television]] stations, as it was cost-prohibitive for many of them to convert to digital transmission.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/articles/2007/11/15/daily.2/?promo|title=For LPTV, DTV Is a Countdown to Disaster|publisher=TVNewsCheck|date=November 15, 2007|accessdate=August 20, 2009}}</ref> The CBA claimed that the new boxes would prevent viewers from being able to watch these analog-only stations; viewers might not even be aware such stations still existed, because the boxes would not list them.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/techinvestor/industry/2008-03-26-small-stations-digital-tv_N.htm|title=Small stations claim digital TV switch will bankrupt them|work=USA Today|date=March 26, 2008|accessdate=August 20, 2009 | first=John | last=Dunbar}}</ref> At the time of the digital transition, the FCC did not set a deadline for existing LPTV stations to convert to digital service; however, it announced that no new analog LPTV stations would be authorized.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fcc.gov/guides/low-power-television-lptv-service | title = Low Power Television (LPTV) Service | work = Consumer and Government Affairs Bureau | publisher = Federal Communications Commission | accessdate =July 7, 2011 }}</ref>
Responding to the CBA, the FCC and NTIA urged manufacturers to include analog support voluntarily in all converter boxes. Manufacturers responded by releasing a new generation of models with the feature. Some new [[DVD recorder]]s and [[personal video recorder]]s also provide both analog and digital tuners, and therefore could perform the basic functions of a set-top box in both modes.
In early May 2008, the D.C. district court denied the CBA petition without comment. The CBA felt that the court wanted them to continue working with the FCC. The association said it would continue to pressure the FCC to support analog functionality as a requirement of the [[All-Channel Receiver Act]], urge more government funding for low power and Class A broadcasters to transition to digital, and ask Congress to increase the number of such stations eligible for funds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tvtechnology.com/pages/s.0157/t.13436.html |title=Court Denies CBA Petition on Analog Pass-Through |work=TV Technology |date=March 9, 2008 |accessdate=August 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724082750/http://tvtechnology.com/pages/s.0157/t.13436.html |archivedate=July 24, 2008 |df=mdy }}</ref>
On August 13, 2009, the CBA announced that it would cease operations. One reason given was the cost required to fight "restrictive regulations that kept the Class A and LPTV industry from realizing its potential", including the campaign to require analog passthrough. Amy Brown, former CBA executive director, said "some 40 percent of Class A and LPTV station operators believe they will have to shut down in the next year if they are not helped through the digital transition."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/327560-Community_Broadcasters_Association_to_Shutter.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv|title=Community Broadcasters Association to Shutter|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=August 13, 2009|accessdate=August 14, 2009}}</ref>
In June 2010, the FCC stopped accepting new applications for digital LPTV stations while it considered the spectrum needs of the [[National Broadband Plan (United States)|National Broadband Plan]].<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.televisionbroadcast.com/article/102784 | title = New LPTV Station Applications Halted by Broadband Demands | date = June 29, 2010 | journal = Television Broadcast | last = McAdams | first = Deborah D. | publisher = NewBay Media | accessdate =July 7, 2011 }}</ref> In a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking published in September 2010, the FCC suggested setting a shutoff date for all analog TV transmissions, including LPTV stations, in 2012.<ref name=fcc-10-172>{{cite report|title=In the Matter of Amendment of Parts 73 and 74 of the Commission's Rules to Establish Rules for Digital Low Power Television, Television Translator, and Television Booster Stations and to Amend Rules for Digital Class A Television Stations: Further Notice of Proposed Rulemaking and Memorandum Opinion and Order |url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2010/db0917/FCC-10-172A1.pdf |author=Federal Communications Commission |year=2010 |publisher=Federal Communications Commission |accessdate=July 7, 2011 |docket=FCC 10-172, MB 03-185 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314024902/http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2010/db0917/FCC-10-172A1.pdf |archivedate=March 14, 2012 |df=mdy }} ({{USFR|2010|26062}})</ref> It also proposed moving all low-power stations on channels 52–69 to new frequencies, to free the 700 MHz band for other uses.<ref name=fcc-10-172/> In April 2011, the NTIA announced that it would stop accepting applications for grants toward upgrading LPTV stations to digital transmission as of July 2, 2012.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.televisionbroadcast.com/article/119896 | title = Fed Sets Deadline on LPTV Upgrade Program | date = April 28, 2011 | last = McAdams | first = Deborah | journal = Television Broadcast | accessdate =July 7, 2011}}</ref> The grant program was initially funded with $44 million; {{as of|2011|06|lc=y}}, over $30 million in grant funding remained available.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ntia.doc.gov/lptv/index.html | title = Low Power Television and Translator Digital Upgrade Program | work = Digital Television Transition and Public Safety | publisher = National Telecommunications and Information Administration, U.S. Department of Commerce | date = June 6, 2011 | accessdate =July 7, 2011 }}</ref>
The final deadline for LPTV Shutdown is 1 September 2015. The last NTIA grants offered to LPTV Broadcasters/Repeaters to convert their systems to digital ended in July 2012. The September 2015 deadline is to allow for possible new construction to accommodate digital equipment.<ref>[http://www.broadcastlawblog.com/2011/07/articles/low-power-televisionclass-a-tv/fcc-sets-deadlines-for-lptv-tv-translator-and-class-a-stations-to-convert-to-digital-and-gives-hints-when-television-spectrum-may-be-reclaimed-for-broadband/ FCC Sets Deadlines for LPTV, TV Translator and Class A Stations To Convert to Digital - And Gives Hints When Television Spectrum May Be Reclaimed for Broadband] ''Broadcast Law Blog'' July 19, 2011</ref> Unlike the TV Full-Power Transmitter Digital Conversion in 2009, there will be no consumer subsidy program for the final LPTV digital conversion deadline since it is anticipated that without DTV Set-Top Converter Boxes, the majority of remaining SDTV/EDTV models in use should have left the consumer market by then.
== End of subsidies == By early January 2009, the NTIA had issued $1.34 billion worth of coupons for converter boxes, reaching the obligation limit set by the U.S. Congress in the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Act of 2005. As a result, the NTIA started placing requests for coupons on a waiting list, issuing coupons as previously-issued but unredeemed coupons reached their expiration date.<ref>{{cite press release | url = http://www.ntia.doc.gov/press/2009/DTV_WaitList_090105.html | title = Commerce's NTIA Announces New Coupon Applicants Will be Placed on Waiting List Due to High Demand for TV Converter Box Coupons | publisher = National Telecommunications and Information Administration, U.S. Department of Commerce | date = January 5, 2009 | accessdate =July 7, 2011}}</ref>
In December 2008, FCC commissioner McDowell urged "those who don't need the government subsidy not to wait on that process before purchasing a converter box for themselves or as a gift for someone else. During the weeks it takes for the government to process coupon requests, you will lose precious time to hook up the box, check antenna connections, and start enjoying free digital broadcast TV right away."<ref>{{cite report | url = http://www.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2008/db1224/FCC-08-281A6.txt | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090123144112/http://www.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2008/db1224/FCC-08-281A6.txt | archivedate = January 23, 2009 | publisher = Federal Communications Commission | last = McDowell | first = Robert M. | title = Statement of Commissioner Robert M. McDowell Re: Implementation of Short-term Analog Flash and Emergency Readiness Act; Establishment of DTV Transition "Analog Nightlight" Program | docket = MB 08-255; FCC 08-281}}</ref>
[[Nielsen Media Research]] estimated in August 2008 that 25 percent of affected viewers would opt for inexpensive converters instead of replacing existing televisions or switching to [[cable television|cable]] and satellite television subscriptions.{{citation needed|date=July 2011}} By November 2008, 38.3 percent were planning to buy the less-costly converter boxes.{{citation needed|date=July 2011}}
Many retailers had stocked converters based on coupon use and shortages of the converter boxes themselves remained possible.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/4247992/ | title = Cash for digital TV converter-box coupons runs out | last = Laliberte | first = Monica | work = WRAL | location = Raleigh, NC | date = January 5, 2009 | publisher = Capitol Broadcasting Company | accessdate =July 7, 2011}}</ref> In early February 2009, the [[Consumer Electronics Association]] estimated that three to six million converters were available,<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/173700-Worst_Case_Converter_Boxes_Could_Run_Out_By_End_Of_Month.php | title = Worst Case: Converter Boxes Could Run Out By End Of Month | last = Eggerton | first = John | journal = Broadcasting & Cable | date = February 5, 2009 | publisher = NewBay Media | accessdate =July 7, 2011}}</ref> while Nielsen estimated 5.8 million American households were completely unready for digital transition.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} The ''New York Times'' estimated that converter supplies could run out by the end of the month.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/02/06/forget-coupons-are-there-enough-dtv-converters/?apage=1 | title = Forget Coupons—Are There Enough DTV Converters? | first= Saul |last= Hansell | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = February 6, 2009 | accessdate =July 7, 2011 | location = New York}}</ref> Manufacturers who had halted production ahead of the original February 17, 2009 deadline were to resume converter box assembly but this new stock was not expected in stores until April.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29056983/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/t/industry-dtv-converter-boxes-could-run-out/ | title = Industry: DTV Converter Boxes Could Run Out | agency = [[Associated Press]]| date=February 6, 2009 | last = Svensson |first = Peter | newspaper = MSNBC | accessdate =July 7, 2011 | publisher = NBC Universal}}</ref>
Legislators from the American southwest were among those supporting a delay in the digital cutover, citing safety concerns because as many as a quarter of households in television markets there had not prepared to receive digital signals by January 2009. A judge from Hildago County, Texas noted that Latino, low-income, elderly, and rural homes were at risk.<ref name=saen>{{cite news | url = http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/state/38437874.html | title = Border areas lag in being ready for digital TV switch| first = Lynn | last = Brezosky | newspaper = [[San Antonio Express-News]] | date = January 27, 2009 | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20090129224405/http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/state/38437874.html | archivedate = January 29, 2009 | accessdate =July 7, 2011}}</ref> Some residents could receive analog signals from Mexico;<ref name=saen/> Mexico does not plan to transition to digital transmission until [[Digital television in Mexico|the end of 2015]].
=== DTV Delay Act === The [[DTV Delay Act]], signed into law on February 11, 2009, extended the digital transition deadline to June 12, 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/televisionNews/idUKTRE5136YP20090204 | title = Congress approves digital TV delay | first = Kim | last = Dixon| work= Reuters| date = February 4, 2009 | accessdate =July 9, 2011 | publisher = Thomson Reuters }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/174041-Obama_Signs_DTV_Delay_Bill.php | title = Obama Signs DTV-Delay Bill | journal = Broadcasting & Cable | date = February 11, 2009 | last = Eggerton | first = John | accessdate =July 9, 2011 | publisher = NewBay Media }}</ref> The DTV Delay Act did not address the shortfall in funding for converter-box coupons; the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act]], part of a larger appropriations bill signed into law on February 17, 2009, added $650 million in funding—$490 million of that for coupons, increasing the total coupon-fund expenditure to $1.83 billion.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/industryNews/idUKTRE51G5ZG20090218 | title = DTV coupon backlog seen gone within weeks |agency=Reuters | date = February 18, 2009 | last = Dixon | first = Kim | publisher = Thomson Reuters | accessdate =July 9, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=migoya>{{cite news | url = http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_11988674 | title = Those with expired coupons for digital-converter boxes may now reapply | first = David | last = Migoya | newspaper = [[The Denver Post]]| date= March 25, 2009 | location = Denver, CO | accessdate =July 9, 2011}}</ref><ref name=exceeds>{{cite journal|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/316344-Government_Exceeds_Original_Converter_Box_Coupon_Funding_Limit.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv |title=Government Exceeds Original Converter Box Coupon Funding Limit|last=Eggerton |first=John |date=July 24, 2009|journal=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |accessdate=August 3, 2009 | publisher = NewBay Media}}</ref> By February 18, 36 percent of the United States's full-power stations had transitioned to digital-only, but five million of the nation's 115 million households remained entirely unready;<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.tvweek.com/news/2009/02/dtv_switch_report_5_mil_homes.php |title=DTV Switch Report: 5 Mil Homes Not Ready |first=Greg |last=Baumann |journal=TV Week |date=February 18, 2009 |accessdate=July 9, 2011 |publisher=Crain Communications |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323170929/http://www.tvweek.com/news/2009/02/dtv_switch_report_5_mil_homes.php |archivedate=March 23, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref> at the time, 4.3 million coupon requests remained on the NTIA waiting list.<ref name="NTIA stats"/> The NTIA resumed issuing coupons in early March 2009, expecting to clear its backlog in two and a half weeks.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29530464/ | title = TV converter box coupons start flowing again | work = [[MSNBC]] | date = March 5, 2009 | agency = Associated Press | accessdate =July 9, 2011}}</ref> Political issues had contributed to the delays in sending out coupons; the NTIA could not issue coupons above the spending limit set in the bill, even knowing that many already-issued coupons would expire.<ref name=reg-muddle>{{cite news|title=Regulatory muddle stalled DTV switch |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2008746214_dtv15.html |last=Hart |first=Kim |last2=Whoriskey |first2=Peter |newspaper=The Seattle Times |location=Seattle, WA |date=February 15, 2009 |accessdate=July 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524144940/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2008746214_dtv15.html |archivedate=May 24, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref> Even though unused coupons meant more money for the program, the coupons had to actually expire before the money could be "reused" for newly issued coupons.<ref name=final>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/328786-Treasury_to_Get_Nine_Figure_Return_On_Coupon_Program.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv |title=Treasury to Get Nine-Figure Return On Coupon Program|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=August 24, 2009|accessdate=August 26, 2009 | publisher = NewBay Media}}</ref> Those coupons it did send out were sent via [[United States Postal Service#Bulk mail|standard mail]], rather than [[United States Postal Service#General domestic services|first-class mail]], as Congress had required in the legislation, but that caused coupons to be delayed up to four weeks.<ref name=reg-muddle/>
The NTIA was legally required to issue coupons on a first-come, first-served basis; viewers in markets where individual stations ended analog broadcasts by the original deadline did not receive priority handling of their DTV coupon requests.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/2009-02-16-dtv-coupons_N.htm | title = Backlog still large for TV converter box coupons | first = Peter | last = Svensson | agency= [[Associated Press]] | newspaper = USA Today | date = January 14, 2009 | accessdate =July 9, 2011 | publisher = Gannett }}</ref>
On March 24, 2009, the NTIA announced that the four-million-person waiting-list backlog had been cleared, meaning those whose coupons had expired could reapply. The NTIA estimated 17 million coupons had expired, while 25.7 million—56 percent of those issued—had been used.<ref name=migoya/> On April 12, Nielsen estimated that 3.6 million households remained unready.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/tampabay/stories/2009/04/13/daily51.html |title=Digital TV transition becoming more common in Tampa-St. Pete |date=April 16, 2009|work=[[Tampa Bay Business Journal]]|accessdate=June 25, 2009}}</ref>
=== Completing the transition === The [[analog shutdown]] for full-power TV stations was completed in mid-2009, with several stations ending analog transmissions well before the June 12, 2009 deadline. (Many transitioned on the original February 17 date.) In most cases, at least one station in each [[media market]] continued analog broadcasts for up to 30 days afterward as an "[[analog nightlight]]"—prohibited from broadcasting regular programming, but allowed to transmit information on how to obtain and connect a converter box to receive digital programming (and send [[Emergency Alert System]] broadcasts.). This allowed viewers who had not converted by the deadline to receive at least one channel that would explain the absence of the other analog channels. The half-hour [[public service announcement]] with English and Spanish segments seen on most such stations was produced by the [[National Association of Broadcasters]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
Nielsen said 2.5 million homes were still incapable of receiving a digital signal two days after the deadline.<ref name=stillnot/> On June 17, 2009, the NTIA said two million requested coupons had not yet been mailed.<ref name=stillnot>{{cite news|url=http://www.multichannel.com/article/294834-2_5_Million_Households_Still_Not_Receiving_DTV_Signals.php?rssid=20059&q=converter+box |title=2.5 Million Households Still Not Receiving DTV Signals |last=Eggerton |first=John |date=June 17, 2009|work=[[Multichannel News]]|accessdate=June 18, 2009}}</ref>
The NTIA reported that, as of July 22, 2009, 33,578,000 coupons had been used—more than the 33.5 million possible with the original $1.34 billion allocation. $435 million of the extra money added was already owed for pending requests.<ref name=exceeds/>
U.S. Representative [[Peter DeFazio]] and Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] introduced legislation which would have extended the converter-box coupon program beyond July 31, 2009, subsidized antennas, and require satellite and cable TV companies to provide a $10 basic-broadcast-channel package available to those who had lost the ability to receive at least one over-the-air channel because of the transition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/294816-House_Version_of_Sanders_DTV_Bill_Introduced.php |title=House Version of Sanders DTV Bill Introduced |last=Eggerton |first=John |date=June 17, 2009|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|accessdate=July 8, 2009}}</ref> Neither Congressman's bill was passed into law.<ref>{{USBill|110|sres|3740}}</ref><ref>{{USBill|111|hres|2867}}</ref>
At midnight on July 31, 2009, the CECB program expired, without extension.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} Toward the end of July, consumers were making 35,000 requests for coupons per day, with just over half those issued being used.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/326025-Nielsen_98_9_of_U_S_Homes_Can_Get_DTV_Signal.php?rssid=20068&q=digital+tv |title=Nielsen: 98.9% of U.S. Homes Can Get DTV Signal |last=Eggerton |first=John |date=July 30, 2009|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]] |accessdate=August 3, 2009}}</ref> On July 30, though, the number of requests totalled 78,000, and on the final day, 169,000 were received.<ref name=cecb-spike/> Requests sent via mail with a postmark of July 31 or earlier were processed; about $300 million in funding remained. By August 5, 2009, consumers had used 33,962,696 coupons.<ref name=cecb-spike>{{cite news|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/326586-Converter_Box_Coupon_Program_Ends_With_Spike_in_Applications.php?rssid=20065&q=digital+tv|title= Converter Box Coupon Program Ends With Spike in Applications|first=John|last=Eggerton|date=August 7, 2009|accessdate=August 7, 2009}}</ref>
The NTIA said 4,287,379 coupons had been requested but not redeemed. As of August 12, $310,796,690 was available, and if all requested coupons were redeemed, $139,300,174 would be left.<ref name=final/>
An unidentified NTIA source said the agency returned $241.6 million to the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Treasury Department]]; $2.6 million went to "final closeout costs".<ref name=unused/> After the program ended, $250 million from the original bill had not been used, and the additional $490 million allocated in February 2009 had not been touched.<ref name=unused>{{cite news|url= http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/441544-Source_Almost_490_Million_Unused_from_DTV_Coupon_Funding.php?rssid=20065&q=digital+tv|title= Source: Almost $490 Million Unused from DTV Coupon Funding|first=John|last=Eggerton|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=December 22, 2009|accessdate=January 13, 2010}}</ref> These funds almost equalled the $490 million Congress had appropriated to boost the program in January 2008, when it appeared the program would run out of money.<ref name=unused/> The additional funding was needed to satisfy the accounting rules imposed on the program by Congress, rather than an actual need for the funds.<ref name=unused/> The unused funds from the original bill went to a DTV public safety fund, as required in the legislation.<ref name=unused/>
== Notes == {{reflist|group=nb}}
== References == ;General {{refbegin}} * ''Title III of the Deficit Reduction Act of 2005'', Pub. No. 109-171 (Feb. 8, 2006). * ''Request for Comment and Notice of Proposed Rules to Implement and Administer a Coupon Program for Digital-to-Analog Converter Boxes'', Docket Number 060512129-6129-01 (Jul. 25, 2006). {{refend}} ;Specific {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.ntia.doc.gov/otiahome/dtv/index.html National Telecommunications & Information Administration DTV website], with [http://www.ntia.doc.gov/ntiahome/press/2007/DTVfinalrule_031207.htm Commerce Department Final Rules] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090606192357/http://www.keepuson.com/index2.php KeepUsOn.com (archived)], by the Community Broadcasters Association, promoting analog support in CECBs
{{North American DTV}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coupon-Eligible Converter Box}} [[Category:Consumer electronics]] [[Category:Film and video technology]] [[Category:Television technology]] [[Category:Set-top box]] [[Category:Social programs]] [[Category:Television in the United States]]

revision.comment: clean up, removed underlinked tag using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=March 2012}} {{notability|date=April 2009}} }}
'''Dandia Dhamaka''' (dD) is an [[India]]n [[Dandiya Raas]] dance competition. In 2001, students from the [[University of Michigan]] created an organization called the RAAS Association to coordinate Dandia Dhamaka. Dandia Dhamaka showcases the South Asian traditional dance form of raas, a traditional, yet expressive form of [[Folk dance in India|Indian folk dance]] involving wooden sticks called dandias, representing the swords of [[Durga]]. The dancers hit each other's sticks to the beat of the music. The women wear traditional dresses such as colorful embroidered [[choli]], [[Gagra choli|ghagra]] and bandhani [[dupattas]] (traditional attire) that shine with mirror work and heavy jewellery. The men wear special [[turbans]] and kedias, but this varies regionally.<ref>http://www.annarbor.com/entertainment/top-college-indian-dance-teams-compete-at-ums-dandia-dhamaka/</ref>
The 2013 competition was held on January 26, 2013 at the [[Michigan Theater (Ann Arbor, Michigan)|Michigan Theater]] in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]].
Dandia Dhamaka has held mixers on the Friday night that teams have arrived at the competition. These mixers allow teams to participate in team building activities so teams can interact with their own teams and their competing teams.
==Placings==
===2014=== # [[University of Illinois at Chicago|University of Illinois - Chicago]] # [[University of Pittsburgh]] # [[Michigan State University]]
===2013=== # Michigan State University # University of Illinois - Chicago # [[Saint Louis University]]
===2012=== # [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois - Urbana Champaign]] # [[Rutgers University]] # Michigan State University
===2011=== # Rutgers University # University of Michigan # Michigan State University
===2010=== # University of Illinois - Urbana-Champaign # University of Michigan # St. Louis University
===2009=== # University of Illinois - Urbana-Champaign # Michigan State University # Washington University - St. Louis
===2008=== # New York University # University of Illinois - Urbana-Champaign # Michigan State University
===2007=== # University of Michigan # University of Illinois - Chicago # Ohio State University

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
'''Dawn O'Donnell''' (born 1927/1928 – died 10 June 2007), was a prominent Sydney [[entrepreneur]] and supporter of the Sydney LGBT community.<ref name=smh1>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/gay-sydney-says-goodbye/2007/06/15/1181414542675.html|title=Gay Sydney says goodbye to one who made it so|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=16 June 2007|accessdate=16 June 2007}}</ref> She has been credited with being a defining early influence on the gay and lesbian club scene in Sydney's [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]] and [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]].<ref name=smh2>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/obituaries/a-leading-lady-of-sydneys-gay-club-scene/2007/06/12/1181414295974.html|title=Obituaries: A leading lady of Sydney's gay club scene|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=13 June 2007|accessdate=16 June 2007}}</ref>
==Early life== Born circa 1928 in the Sydney suburb of [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]], she won a bursary to St Vincent's College, [[Potts Point]], run by the [[Sisters of Charity]]. She left school at age 15, and three years later, aged 18, won the Australian ladies speed skating championship, turned professional and taught at the Glaciarium before going to London and Paris. She was briefly married to a butcher named Des Irwin.<ref name="ninglun"/> Her career began as an international [[Ice skating|ice skater]] when she was a teenager. It was while touring Paris as a performer in the ''[[Puss in Boots (fairy tale)|Puss in Boots]]'' on ice show, she had her first romance with another woman.<ref name=smh2/>
==Career== After her promising skating career was cut short by injury, O'Donnell ran a butcher shop in [[Double Bay, New South Wales|Double Bay]] and a [[parking lot]] in [[Ultimo, New South Wales|Ultimo]], before opening her first [[gay bar]], '''The Trolley Bar''', off [[Broadway, New South Wales|Broadway]] in 1968. Next she opened a gay bath-house (above a cake shop in [[Bondi Junction, New South Wales]]), followed in 1969 by '''Capriccio's''', a gay night club on [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]] famous for its [[Drag queen|drag]] shows, which drew visiting celebrities from around the world.<ref name=smh2/>
She recognised the gay and lesbian potential of [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]]. At this time, homosexual acts between men were still illegal in [[New South Wales]], and Dawn O'Donnell was known to pay bail to release gay men from police custody. Her gay and lesbian venues gave many "a place to [[Coming out|come out]]".<ref name=smh1/> In 2001, O'Donnell recounted: ''"The most fascinating thing in the world for me was eventually to see the [[New South Wales Police Force]] have a gay public relations officer. I never thought to my dying day I'd ever see that."''<ref name=abc1>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/stories/s251185.htm|title=Exhibition reveals a century of gay life|publisher=ABC News 'Lateline'|date=23 February 2001|accessdate=16 June 2007}}</ref>
Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, O'Donnell controlled a string of lesbian and gay venues in [[East Sydney, New South Wales|East Sydney]], including: * '''Jools''' on [[Crown Street, Sydney|Crown Street]] * '''Patchs''' nightclub on [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]] * '''Flo's Palace''' * '''The Exchange Hotel''' * '''Ruby Reds''' on [[Crown Street, Sydney|Crown Street]] (Sydney's first lesbian bar)
Some of these ventures were run in partnership with the late French restaurateur Roger Claude Teyssedre and controversial Sydney businessman [[Abe Saffron]].<ref name=smh2/> The clubs attracted gays and lesbians from across Australia and around the world.<ref name=aus1>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21889969-2702,00.html|title=Mother of gay Sydney dies at 79|publisher=The Australian|date=12 June 2007|accessdate=3 August 2007}}</ref>
During the 1980s, O'Donnell began to shift her focus from [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]] to the inner-west suburb of [[Newtown, New South Wales|Newtown]]. She bought the Newtown and Imperial Hotels in nearby [[Erskineville, New South Wales|Erskineville]], transforming the Newtown area into a gay precinct to rival [[Oxford Street, Sydney|Oxford Street]]. The Imperial Hotel featured in the opening scenes of the movie, ''[[The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert]]''. {{Citation needed|date=August 2009}}
According to Graeme Browning (a.k.a. "Mitzi Macintosh") who performed [[Drag queen|drag]] shows at O'Donnell-owned venues for 10 years, "She made the Sydney drag scene what it is, but our gay scene wouldn't be what it is without her either." Another [[Drag queen|drag]] performer, David Williams (aka "Beatrice") said "she invented the idea of Oxford Street", helping to make Sydney one of the gay capitals of the world.<ref name=smh1/>
==Personal life and death== In 1977, aged 49, O'Donnell met her long-term partner, [[Dutch (ethnic group)|Dutch]]-born Aniek Baten, who was 26 years old. They later married, both wearing white for the wedding. <ref name="ninglun">[http://ninglun.wordpress.com/2007/06/16/dawn-odonnell-died-on-queens-birthday-weekend-aged-79 Dawn O'Donnell obituary], wordpress.com, 16 June 2007; accessed 24 March 2014.</ref> Their relationship continued until O'Donnell's death from [[ovarian cancer]], aged 79, on Sunday, 10 June 2007. O'Donnell's funeral service was held at St Canice's Catholic Church in [[Elizabeth Bay, New South Wales|Elizabeth Bay]], Sydney.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}}
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name=Employee Appreciation Day |observedby= [[United States]], [[Canada]], |date=First Friday in March |duration=1 day |frequency=annual |scheduling= |weekday= Friday |week_ordinal=first |month=March }} '''Employee Appreciation Day''' is an [[holiday#unofficial holiday|unofficial holiday]] observed on the first Friday in March in the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom. It is a day for companies to thank their employees for their hard work and effort throughout the year. This day was created for the purpose of strengthening the bond between employer and employee.
Though the holiday is still gaining in adoption in the U.S. and abroad, like [[Boss's Day]], Employee Appreciation Day has become an opportunity for managers, company leadership and HR to remember the importance of appreciating employees.<ref name="t&d">{{cite web|title=Time and Date — Employee Appreciation Day in United States|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/us/employee-appreciation-day|publisher=Timeanddate.com|accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref> Companies often celebrate by letting employees leave early,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lisaquast/2017/02/27/5-ways-to-celebrate-employee-appreciation-day-friday-march-3rd/#6f91d01b2c7f|title=5 Ways To Celebrate Employee Appreciation Day|last=Quast|first=Lisa|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-02|language=en}}</ref> offering gifts, events or special recognition for workers.<ref name="Inc - 5 Ideas for Employee Appreciation Day">{{cite web|title= Inc - 5 Great Ideas for Employee Appreciation Day|url=http://www.inc.com/suzanne-lucas/5-great-ideas-for-employee-appreciation-day.html|publisher=Inc.com|accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref> Studies show that recognition and appreciation are growing in importance as drivers of employee happiness and engagement. This has resulted in more and more companies and organizations using the day to thank their employees.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Law Review on Employee Appreciation Day|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/some-thoughts-employee-appreciation-day-including-potential-wage-and-hour-pitfall|publisher=Natlawreview.com|accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref>
Many publications such as [[Inc. (magazine)|''Inc.'' magazine]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Inc - 7 Last Minute Ideas for Employee Appreciation Day|url=http://www.inc.com/matthew-swyers/7-last-minute-ideas-for-national-employee-appreciation-day.html|publisher=Inc.com|accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Forbes - 25 Low Cost Ways to Reward Employees|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kevinkruse/2013/03/01/25-low-cost-ways-to-reward-employees/|publisher=Forbes.com|accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref> and [[Boston.com]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Boston.com - What Would You Actually Appreciate?|url=http://www.boston.com/jobs/news/2015/03/03/employee-appreciation-day-poll-what-would-you-actually-appreciate/MFidNnnSb8eNnaRKtAiOFO/story.html|publisher=Boston.com|accessdate=2015-03-30}}</ref> are writing about the holiday to remind employers to recognize and reward employee effort and to offer tips for building a stronger corporate culture through appreciation. Showing employees appreciation can result in a company's higher retention rate, not only increasing the productivity of employees but the company as a whole. <ref>{{cite web|title=The Benefits of Employee Recognition|url=https://www.fineawards.com/blog/the-benefits-of-employee-recognition/|website=FineAwards.com|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
