{{DISPLAYTITLE:Music of the ''Drakengard'' series}} {{good article}} The music for the ''[[Drakengard (series)|Drakengard]]'' series, known as {{nihongo|''Drag-On Dragoon''|ドラッグ オン ドラグーン|Doraggu on doragūn|commonly abbreviated as ''DOD''|lead=no}} in Japan, has been handled by multiple composers since the release of the [[Drakengard|original game]] in 2004. ''Drakengard''{{'}}s composers were [[Nobuyoshi Sano]] and Takayuki Aihara, ''[[Drakengard 2]]'' was handled by Ryoki Matsumoto and Aoi Yoshiki, and ''[[Drakengard 3]]'' was composed for by Keiichi Okabe, the composer for series spin-off ''[[Nier (video game)|Nier]]''. Sano remained as a sound director for the second game, and his music was used as a reference for the third. Multiple albums have been released for the music of the series: ''Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack Vol.1'' and ''Vol.2'' were released on October and November 2004, while a two-disc re-release titled ''Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack'' was released in April 2011. The ''Drag-On Dragoon 2 Original Soundtrack'' was released on July 20, 2005. A promotional disc with two tracks from the soundtrack was released in the same year. The official soundtrack for the third game, ''Drag-On Dragoon 3 Original Soundtrack'', was released January 21, 2014. An compilation of [[chiptune]] remixes of the previous games and ''Nier'', ''Drag-On Dragoon Chips Music'', was released on December 19, 2013 as part of the ''Drag-On Dragoon 10 Anniversary Box''. The series has also received theme songs from multiple Japanese pop artists, all of which have been released as singles. A re-orchestration of [[Mika Nakashima]]'s single "Hitori" was used as the theme for ''Drakengard 2'', incorporating elements from the game. Two theme songs were written for ''Drakengard 3'': "Kuroi Uta" and "This Silence is Mine". The former was sung by [[Eir Aoi]], a fan of the series, and written by ''Nier'' writer Kikuchi Hana. The latter was specially written and sung by [[Onitsuka Chihiro]], who created the song around the themes and characters of the game. Both songs were composed by Okabe. All three singles have been in the top 40 best-selling singles in the Japanese [[Oricon]] music charts. The soundtracks have received mixed to positive reviews from both dedicated video game music outlets and video game critics. The first game was noted for its disturbing style, which both drew criticism for repetitiveness and praise for suiting the game's atmosphere. It has been generally cited as an experimental soundtrack. The second game's soundtrack received a more positive reception, with the general opinion being that it was a more traditional and consequently more comfortable soundtrack. The third game's soundtrack also received fairly positive comments, mainly praising its quality, although critiques were made concerning its variety. The chiptune compilation was generally liked, except for its exclusivity to the special release. The singles have also received praise. ==Creation and influence== The music of the [[Drakengard|first game]] in the [[Drakengard (series)|''Drakengard'' series]] was composed by [[Nobuyoshi Sano]] and Takayuki Aihara. In creating the score, they sampled excerpts from pieces of classical music (selected by Aihara), then rearranged, remixed and layered them in various ways. Their main objective was to create music that emulated the game's hack-and-slash gameplay, as well as the dark story and general narrative theme of "madness". The music was intended to be "experimental" and "expressionistic" rather than "commercial". After being composed, all the tracks were performed by a full orchestra.{{cite web|url=http://www.squareenixmusic.com/features/liners/drakengard.shtml|title=Drag-on Dragoon Original Soundtrack :: Liner Notes Translated by Ben Schweitzer|author=Schweitzer, Ben|publisher=Square Enix Music Online|accessdate=2014-02-15|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222144620/http://www.squareenixmusic.com/features/liners/drakengard.shtml|archivedate=2014-02-22|deadurl=yes}} The team who worked on the music also worked on the ''[[Tekken]]'' series, and they sought to emulate the music of [[Northern Europe]].{{cite web | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/05/22/drakengard-interview?page=1| title=Drakengard Interview | accessdate=2013-08-24 | author=Dunham, Jeremy | date=2003-05-23| publisher=[[IGN]]}} One of the soundtracks that inspired Sano and Aihara in their work was the score for ''[[The Exorcist (film)|The Exorcist]]''.{{cite web|url=http://game.watch.impress.co.jp/docs/20031110/dod.htm|script-title=ja:「ドラッグ オン ドラグーン」サウンドクリエイター インタビュー|language=Japanese|publisher=Game Watch|date=2003-11-10|accessdate=2014-09-26}} The theme song, {{nihongo|"Exhausted"|尽きる|Tsukiru}}, was composed by Sano, written by the game's scenario writer Sawako Natori and sung by [[Eriko Hatsune]].{{cite web|url=http://www.squareenixmusic.com/lyrics/drakengard/exhausted.shtml|title=Square Enix Music Online :: Drakengard - Exhausted|publisher=Square Enix Music Online|accessdate=2014-03-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301164247/http://www.squareenixmusic.com/lyrics/drakengard/exhausted.shtml|archivedate=2014-03-01|deadurl=yes}} ''[[Drakengard 2]]''{{'}}s soundtrack was composed by Ryoki Matsumoto and Aoi Yoshiki, with supervision by Sano, who acted as sound director.{{cite web|url=http://www.squareenixmusic.com/features/liners/drakengard2.shtml|title=Drag-on Dragoon 2 Original Soundtrack :: Liner Notes Translated by Ben Schweitzer|last=Schweitzer|first=Ben|publisher=Square Enix Music Online|accessdate=2014-02-15|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210102347/http://squareenixmusic.com/features/liners/drakengard2.shtml|archivedate=2013-12-10|deadurl=yes|df=}} The CGI cutscenes were scored by Masashi Yano.{{cite web|url=http://www.aqi.co.jp/product/bulletwitch/blog/2006/06/index.html|script-title=ja:Bullet Witch / Staff Blog / 2006年6月|language=Japanese|publisher=Bullet Witch Official Blog|accessdate=2017-06-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528115040/http://www.aqi.co.jp/product/bulletwitch/blog/2006/06/index.html|archivedate=2007-05-28|deadurl=yes}} Due to widespread criticisms of his work on the first game, Sano was asked by the game's producer, Takamasa Shiba, to bring in outside help for the second game's soundtrack, which upset Sano to a degree. Shiba wanted a composer less linked to video games to compose the music: Matsumoto was brought in because of his work on the non-video-game [[J-pop]] songs "[[Yuki no Hana]]" and "Tsuki no Shizuku". Because of the size of the project, Matsumoto in turn brought in his friend Yoshiki to help. The soundtrack was designed a fusion of J-pop and video game music, and to evoke the emotions of the various characters and the feeling of battle.{{cite web|url=http://dengekionline.com/data/news/2005/7/8/82cf6ea966daf55a023c7a6a3c474d80.html|script-title=ja:“融合”をテーマにした『ドラッグオンドラグーン2』のサウンドトラックが7月20日発売|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works|Dengeki Online]]|date=2005-07-08|accessdate=2014-01-05}} The theme song for the game's English release was "Growing Wings", a localized version of the first game's theme song sung by [[Kari Wahlgren]].{{cite web|url=http://www.squareenixmusic.com/lyrics/drakengard/growingwings.shtml|title=Square Enix Music Online :: Drakengard 2 - Growing Wings|publisher=Square Enix Music Online|accessdate=2014-03-01|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301151216/http://www.squareenixmusic.com/lyrics/drakengard/growingwings.shtml|archivedate=2014-03-01|deadurl=no}} [[Drakengard 3|The third game]]'s music was composed by Keiichi Okabe, who also created the [[Music of Nier|score for ''Nier'']], a spin-off game of the series. While writing the music, Okabe felt he needed to match Sano's work on ''Drakengard'', rather than copy it, and so felt that there was no need to "rehash" the original music despite the potential merits. He commented that the musical creation was "a tough production, but for this game, there's part of it I'm doing that I've never experienced before."{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/7/17/4530966/abot-drakengard-3-and-making-the-music-for-a-very-strange-game|title=Drakengard 3 will not 'feel much like a Square Enix' release, if music department has its way|author=Gifford, Kevin|publisher=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=2013-07-17|accessdate=2013-10-09}} At director [[Taro Yoko]]'s request, Okabe worked on separating the style of the music from that of ''[[Nier (video game)|Nier]]'': he did this by including both soft, gentle tunes similar to ''Nier'' and more intense tracks. The two styles were also inspired by the game's world theme of "the sense of contrast".{{cite web |url=http://www.siliconera.com/2014/05/06/drakengard-3-sound-director-music-different-niers/ |title=Drakengard 3 Sound Director On How The Music Is Different From Nier's |author=Ishaan |publisher=Siliconera |accessdate=2014-05-08 |date=2014-05-06 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508100605/http://www.siliconera.com/2014/05/06/drakengard-3-sound-director-music-different-niers/ |archivedate=2014-05-08 |deadurl=no}} One musical piece, "Exhausted 3", is a re-orchestration of ''Drakengard''{{'}}s theme song, intended by Okabe as a nod to earlier installments while staying true to Yoko's wishes. ==Albums== ===''Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack''=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Nobuyoshi Sano]] & Takayuki Aihara | cover = DOD OST cover.jpg | alt = | released = October 22, 2003 (Vol.1)
November 21, 2003 (Vol.2)
April 20, 2011 (Re-release) | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 1:03:14 (Vol.1/Disc 1)
1:15:50 (Vol.2/Disc 2) | label = [[Marvelous Entertainment]] | producer = [[Square Enix]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} Music from ''Drag-on Dragoon'' has been released in several albums. The soundtrack was originally released in two volumes under the names ''Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack Vol.1'' and ''Vol.2'', released on October 22 and November 21, 2003 respectively. The soundtrack was re-released on April 20, 2011 as a two-disc set under the title ''Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack''.{{cite web |url=http://store.jp.square-enix.com/detail/SQEX-10239-40 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140301115731/http://store.jp.square-enix.com/detail/SQEX-10239-40 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-03-01 |script-title=ja:【再発盤】ドラッグ オン ドラグーン オリジナル・サウンドトラック |language=Japanese |publisher=Square Enix |accessdate=2014-03-01 }} The re-release reached #57 in the Japanese [[Oricon]] music charts and remained in the charts for two weeks.{{cite web| url = http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/67810/products/907393/1/| publisher = [[Oricon]]| script-title=ja:ドラッグ オン ドラグーン オリジナル・サウンドトラック |language = Japanese | accessdate=2014-11-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110125808/http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/67810/products/907393/1/ |archivedate=2014-11-10 |deadurl=no}} The individual albums received a mixed response from critics. The reviewer for ''RPGFan'' was weakly positive about the first album, calling it "extremely experimental" and stating that people needed to be open-minded while listening, while also citing it as better than the soundtrack for ''[[Xenosaga Episode I: Der Wille zur Macht]]''.{{cite web | title=Drag-on Dragoon OST Vol. 1 | url = http://www.rpgfan.com/soundtracks/drag-on1/index.html |publisher=RPGFan | author=Dragon God | accessdate=2008-07-07}} The reviewer echoed most of these sentiments for the second album, while also stating that it contained the better musical pieces from the game of the two albums.{{cite web | title=Drag-on Dragoon OST Vol. 2 | url = http://www.rpgfan.com/soundtracks/drag-on2/index.html |publisher=RPGFan | author=Dragon God | accessdate=2008-07-07}} Luc Nadeau of ''Game Music Online'', who reviewed all three releases of the soundtrack, was mixed to positive in his opinions. He generally liked the music, but noted, like the ''RPGFan'' reviewer, that it was highly experimental and would not be to everyone's taste. He also cited his preference for the 2011 two-disc re-release over the original albums.{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/drakengardvol1/|title=Drakengard Original Soundtrack Vol. 1|author=Nadeau, Luc|publisher=Game Music Online|date=2011-08-20|accessdate=2014-09-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/drakengardvol2/|title=Drakengard Original Soundtrack Vol. 2|author=Nadeau, Luc|publisher=Game Music Online|date=2011-08-20|accessdate=2014-09-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/drakengard/|title=Drakengard Original Soundtrack|author=Nadeau, Luc|publisher=Game Music Online|date=2011-08-20|accessdate=2014-09-23}} Reviewing the re-release, Jayson Napolitano of ''Original Sound Version'' called it "one of the most experimental and disturbing soundtracks I've heard in a while". He praised the soundtrack despite not finding it memorable, and commented that he found it more appealing when he knew some of the plot details that were censored in the game's western release.{{cite web|url=http://www.originalsoundversion.com/a-disturbing-experiment-the-drag-on-dragoon-dual-disc-reprint-review/|title=A Disturbing Experiment: The Drag-On Dragoon Dual-Disc Reprint (Review)|author=Napolitano, Jayson|publisher=Original Sound Version|date=2014-05-09|accessdate=2014-11-08}} Reviewers of the game itself also noted the soundtrack. Greg Kasavin of ''[[GameSpot]]'' mentioned it as the most distinctive aspect of the game, stating that it was "the most nerve-racking and most intense aspect of [''Drakengard'']".{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/drakengard-review/1900-6089873/|title=Drakengard Review|author=Kasavin, Greg|publisher=[[GameSpot]] |date=2004-02-23 |accessdate=2013-11-14 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140326064920/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/drakengard-review/1900-6089873/|archivedate=2014-03-26|deadurl=no}} Adam Jarvis of ''VideoGamer.com'' was also positive, calling the soundtrack "haunting" and saying that it "helps create a suitably dark atmosphere".{{cite web|url=http://www.videogamer.com/ps2/drakengard/review.html|title=Drakengard Review|author=Jarvis, Adam|publisher=VideoGamer.com|date=2004-08-20|accessdate=2014-01-04}} ''[[IGN]]''{{'}}s Jeremy Dunham was both impressed by the atmosphere of the tracks and critical of multiple instances of grueling repetition, summing the music up as "disappointing".{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2004/02/13/drakengard-3|title=Drakengard Review|author=Dunham, Jeremy|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2004-02-13|accessdate=2013-11-14}} {{Track listing | collapsed = yes | headline = ''Drag-On Dragoon Original Soundtrack Vol.1'' (disc 1) | total_length = | title1 = Mission Selection | note1 = ミッション選択 | music1 = Nobuyoshi Sano | length1 = 0:25 | title2 = Weapon Selection | note2 = 武器選択 | music2 = Takayuki Aihara | length2 = 1:14 | title3 = First Chapter - In the Sky (Unpublished) | note23 = 第十一章上空（未使用） | music23 = Takayuki Aihara | length23 = 2:49 | title24 = Twelfth Chapter - Closing (Unpublished) | note24 = 第十二章（未使用） | music24 = Nobuyoshi Sano | length24 = 0:52 }} {{-}} ===''Drag-On Dragoon 2 Original Soundtrack''=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Drag-On Dragoon 2 Original Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = Ryoki Matsumoto, Aoi Yoshiki & [[Nobuyoshi Sano]] | cover = | alt = | released = July 20, 2005 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 1:13:03 | label = Square Enix | producer = Sony Music Associated Records | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} Unlike ''Drakengard'', ''Drakengard 2'' has only had one soundtrack album released. ''Drag-On Dragoon 2 Original Soundtrack'' was released on July 20, 2005 under the catalog number ''AICL-1628''. It consists of 22 tracks lasting 1:13:03.{{cite web|url=http://www.game-ost.com/albums/15689/drag-on_dragoon_2_original_soundtrack/|title=Drag-on Dragoon 2 Original Soundtrack|publisher=Game-OST |author=Smith, Simon|accessdate=2014-09-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806003303/http://game-ost.com/albums/15689/drag-on_dragoon_2_original_soundtrack/|archivedate=2014-08-06|deadurl=no}} It contains the tracks used during gameplay and not those used during cutscenes, but does include the game's theme song, "[[Hitori (Mika Nakashima song)|Hitori]]", which was also released as a separate [[Single (music)|single]]. Two tracks from the game were released as a promotional CD for the game, both as a limited giveaway and part of press kits. It included concept art, interviews, and trailers.{{cite web|url=http://www.game-ost.com/albums/44879/drag-on_dragoon_2_web_material/|title=Drag-on Dragoon 2 Web Material|publisher=Game-OST|accessdate=2014-09-24}} The album has received very positive reviews. Chris Greening of ''Game Music Online'' praised the shift to a more classical style and the general intensity of multiple tracks, ending the review by applauding Yoshiki's hard work.{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/drakengard2/|title=Drakengard 2 Original Soundtrack|author=Greening, Chris|publisher=Game Music Online|date=2005-07-20|accessdate=2014-09-24}} Mike Wilson, writing for ''RPGFan'', echoed many of these sentiments despite thinking that there were too few tracks on the album, giving the soundtrack ten out of ten.{{cite web|url=http://rpgfan.com/soundtracks/drag-on-2/index.html|title=Drag-on Dragoon 2 OST|author=Wilson, Mike|publisher=RPGFan|accessdate=2014-09-24}} Both reviewers stated that it was an easier listening experience than the soundtrack for the first ''Drag-on Dragoon'' game. ''Game-OST''{{'}}s Simon Smith also praised it, calling the soundtrack "a complete attack on the senses as an entire orchestra and full sized choir rampage as much power and tension on you as possible." Outside soundtrack reviews, opinions from reviews of the game itself have also been positive. ''IGN''{{'}}s Ed Lewis called the music "appropriately dramatic", though stated it was often drowned out by the ambient noise and voice acting.{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2006/02/16/drakengard-2|title=Drakengard 2|author=Lewis, Ed|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2006-02-16|accessdate=2013-11-14}} ''GameSpot''{{'}}s Greg Mueller called the music "varied and interesting", while stating that the vocal theme was "sappy, but it's used sparingly enough, so it doesn't get terribly annoying".{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/drakengard-2-review/1900-6144299/|title=Drakengard 2 review|author=Mueller, Greg|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|date=2006-02-14|accessdate=2013-11-14|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140215220951/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/drakengard-2-review/1900-6144299/|archivedate=2014-02-15|deadurl=no}} The ''[[GameTrailers]]'' reviewer cited the score as "top-notch", referring to it as one of the few well-done aspects of the game.{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/reviews/uh7rrc/drakengard-2--review|title=Drakengard 2 review|author=|publisher=[[GameTrailers]]|date=2006-07-06|accessdate=2014-01-04}} {{Track listing | headline Soundtrack''=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Drag-On Dragoon 3 Original Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = Keiichi Okabe | cover = | alt = | released = January 21, 2014 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 1:12:48 (disc 1)
1:09:06 (disc 2) | label = [[Square Enix]] | producer = Square Enix | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} Like the second game, there has only been one soundtrack album release for ''Drakengard 3''. ''Drag-on Dragoon 3 Original Soundtrack'' was released on January 21, 2014 under the catalog number ''SQEX-10414~5''. The game's two theme songs were released both as part of the soundtrack and as singles. Christopher Huynh of ''Game Music Online'' generally praised the soundtrack's quality, but felt there was too little variety.{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/drakengard3/|title=Drakengard 3 Original Soundtrack|author=Huynh, Christopher|publisher=Game Music Online|date=2014-05-21|accessdate=2014-09-24}} ''RPGFan''{{'}}s Patrick Gann was generally positive, although he had little commentary on individual tracks, and recommended the album to people who had enjoyed the soundtrack of ''Nier''.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgfan.com/soundtracks/drag-on-3/|title=Drag-on Dragoon 3 OST|author=Gann, Patrick |publisher=RPGFan|date=2014-10-04 |accessdate=2014-10-04}} The album reached #18 in the Oricon charts and remained in the charts for four weeks.{{cite web| url = http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/67810/products/music/1056182/1/| publisher = [[Oricon]]| script-title=ja:Ｄｒａｇ－Ｏｎ　Ｄｒａｇｏｏｎ　３　Ｏｒｉｇｉｎａｌ　Ｓｏｕｎｄｔｒａｃｋ |language = Japanese | accessdate=2014-09-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140930191235/http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/67810/products/music/1056182/1/ |archivedate=2014-09-30 |deadurl=no}} Reviewers of the game have also praised the soundtrack. ''USGamer''{{'}}s Kat Bailey was fairly positive about it despite not finding it very memorable, calling it "aggressively anime, mixing piano riffs with the odd bit of J-Pop for emphasis".{{cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/drakengard-3-review-the-gods-must-be-crazy|title=Drakengard 3 PS3 Review: The Gods Must Be Crazy|author=Bailey, Kat|publisher=USGamer|date=2014-05-20|accessdate=2014-05-30}} Chris Carter of ''[[Destructoid]]'' called the music "stupendous, and one of the best JRPG soundtracks I've heard in a long while."{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-drakengard-3-274631.phtml|title=Review: Drakengard 3|author=Carter, Chris|publisher=[[Destructoid]]|date=2014-05-20|accessdate=2014-09-16}} Andrew Barker, writing an analysis of the game for ''RPGFan'', called the music "the backbone" of ''Drakengard 3''. He also cited the music as being "universally praised" by critics.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgfan.com/news/2014/1854.html|title=Of Blood and Song – An Analysis of Drakengard 3|author=Barker, Andrew|publisher=RPGFan|date=2014-08-08|accessdate=2014-11-08|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022045319/http://www.rpgfan.com/news/2014/1854.html|archivedate=2014-10-22|deadurl=no}} web|url=http://www.game-ost.com/albums/48085/drag-on_dragoon_3_original_soundtrack/|title=DRAG-ON DRAGOON 3 Original Soundtrack|publisher=Game-OST|accessdate=2014-11-10}} | total_length = | title1 = A | title2 = Exvulsion / Phanuel | note2 = 出蠢／ファヌエル | length2 = 4:10 | title3 = Prevolt / Armaros | note3 = 防来／アルマロス | length3 = 3:33 | title4 = Corroscience / Almisael | note4 = 侵贖／アルミサエル | length4 = 4:28 | title8 = Companthem / Abdiel | note8 = 友歌／アブディエル | length8 = 4:15 | title9 = Prevolt / Zophiel | note9 = 防来／ゾフィエル | length9 = 3:33 | title10 = Exvulsion / Galgaliel | note10 = 出蠢／ガルガリエル | length10 = 4:56 | title11 = Corroscience / Ezrael | note11 = 侵贖／イズライール | length11 = 4:35 | title12 = Kuroi Uta (international version) | note12 = クロイウタ／日本国外向け製品収録版 | length12 = 6:05 | title13 = The Final Song | note13 = 最後の歌 | length13 = 7:56 | title14 = This Silence is Mine | note14 = | length14 = 7:06 }} {{-}} ===''Drag-On Dragoon Chips Music''=== {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Drag-On Dragoon Chips Music | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Nobuyoshi Sano]], Takayuki Aihara, Ryoki Matsumoto, Aoi Yoshiki & Keiichi Okabe | cover = | alt = | released = December 19, 2013 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 1:13:03 | label = Square Enix | producer = Square Enix | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} In addition to the soundtrack albums, a single compilation of music from across the series has been produced. ''Drag-On Dragoon Chips Music'' was released on December 19, 2013 under the catalog number ''TGCS-7750''. The release consists of a selection of tracks from ''Drakengard'' (Sano, Aihara), ''Drakengard 2'' (Aoi, Matsumoto) and ''Nier'' (Okabe) remixed as [[chiptune]]s. Also included is a version of "Exhausted" by Sano for the piano, used as background music for ''Drakengard 3''{{'}}s Japanese website. The compilation was exclusively released as part of the ''Drag-On Dragoon 10th Anniversary Box'', featuring a copy of ''Drakengard 3'' and multiple books and artwork relating to the series. The music was accompanied by images representative of scenes from the game where the selected music plays.{{cite web|url=http://dengekionline.com/elem/000/000/758/758304/|script-title=ja:『ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3』10周年記念ボックスが追加受注開始。『DOD』『ニーア』ファン必携の限定版を手に入れるラストチャンス|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works|Dengeki Online]]|date=2013-11-25|accessdate=2014-11-10}} The compilation received mixed to positive opinions from music reviewers. Patrick Gann of ''RPGFan'' was generally positive about the remixes, especially those of tracks from ''Nier''.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgfan.com/soundtracks/drag-on-chips/|title=Drag-on Dragoon Chips Music|author=Gann, Patrick|publisher=RPG Fan|date=|accessdate=2014-11-10}} ''Game Music Online''{{'}}s Christopher Huynh was a little less enthusiastic, saying that there were "some pieces working better than others but none that should be considered bad." His main complaint was that there was little creativity in the remixes.{{cite web|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/drakengardchips/|title=Drakengard Chips Music|author=Huynh, Christopher|publisher=Game Music Online|date=2014-09-12|accessdate=2014-11-10}} Both reviewers were pleased with the piano remix of "Exhausted", and both criticized its exclusivity to the special bundle. {{Track listing | = 武器選択 | writer2 = Takayuki Aihara | length2 = 1:17 | title3 = First Chapter - In the Sky | extra3 = 第一章上空 | writer3 = Aihara | length3 = 2:58 | title4 = Fourth Chapter - On the Ground | extra4 = 4:59 | title18 = Hills of Radiant Wind | writer18 = Okabe | extra18 = 光ノ風吹ク丘 | length18 = 2:53 | title19 = City of Commerce | writer19 = Okabe | extra19 = 売買ノ街 | length19 = 2:18 | title20 = Deep Ashes of Dreams／Aratanaru-Japanese version | length24 = 6:29 | title25 = Exhausted [piano version] / bonus tracks | writer25 = Sano | extra25 = 尽きる「piano version」/bonus tracks | length25 = 4:46 }} {{-}} ==Singles== ==="Hitori"=== {{Infobox song | name = Hitori | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Mika Nakashima]] | album = [[Music (Mika Nakashima album)|Music]] | released = June 8, 2005 | format = [[CD single]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = 5:56 (single ver.) | label = [[Sony Music Entertainment Japan]] | writer = Ryoki Matsumoto, Satomi | producer = | prev_title = [[Sakurairo Mau Koro]] | prev_year = 2005 | next_title = [[Glamorous Sky]] | next_year = 2005 }} {{Main|Hitori (Mika Nakashima song)}} {{nihongo|"Hitori"|ひとり|Alone}} is the theme song for the Japanese version of ''Drakengard 2''. It was sung by [[Mika Nakashima]], composed by Ryoki Matsumoto, and written by Satomi. Nakashima also worked as a producer for the soundtrack.{{cite web|url=http://dengekionline.com/data/news/2005/3/18/788b60bfc23c8d8e8748f7b2a75e4ee3.html|script-title=ja:シリーズ最新作『ドラッグオンドラグーン2』の主題歌を歌うのはあの中島美嘉さん！|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works|Dengeki Online]]|date=2005-03-18|accessdate=2014-01-05}} The song, originally released as part of Nakashima's third album ''[[Music (Mika Nakashima album)|Music]]'', was based on a previous composition for ''[[Star Ocean: The Second Story]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1161658_1124.html|script-title=ja:『DOD2』の主題歌は中島美嘉が歌う『ひとり』|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2005-03-18|accessdate=2014-09-23|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923214946/http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/1161658_1124.html|archivedate=2014-09-23|deadurl=no}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2005/03/21/pop-hottie-for-drakengard-2|title=Pop Hottie for Drakengard 2|author=Dunham, Jeremy|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=2005-03-21|accessdate=2014-01-04}} The song was written as a musical followup to "[[Yuki no Hana]]", and the lyrics were written to include thematic connections to the game's story.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/interview/050608_01_int.html|script-title=ja:中島 美嘉 Special Interview|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Oricon]]|date=|accessdate=2014-09-23|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100817104323/http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/interview/050608_01_int.html|archivedate=2010-08-17|deadurl=no}} The single was released by [[Sony Music Entertainment Japan]] on June 16, 2005, containing four versions of the song. It reached #15 in the Oricon charts upon release and remained in the charts for six weeks.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/285194/products/music/595412/1/|script-title=ja:中島美嘉 - ひとり|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Oricon]]|accessdate=2014-09-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924074839/http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/285194/products/music/595412/1/|archivedate=2014-09-24|deadurl=no}} Opinions on the song have been generally positive. In his review of the soundtrack, ''Game-OST''{{ '}}s Simon Smith called it "a soft jazz song with sultry smooth vocals and a nice tune", and praised it despite it not becoming one of his favorites. Mike Wilson, writing for ''RPGFan'', referred to it as "possibly the most beautiful vocal I've ever heard in a video game." Chris Greening of ''Game Music Online'' called it "a strong rival to every single pop ballad released from Square Enix, proving rich yet accessible." {{Track listing | headline = Track list | collapsed = no | extra_column = Japanese title | title1 = Hitori (single version) | extra1 = ひとり[single version] | length1 = 5:53 | title2 = Hitori (album version) | extra2 = ひとり[album version] | length2 = 5:51 | title3 = Hitori (endroll version) | extra3 = ひとり[endroll version] | length3 = 4:58 | title4 = Hitori (instrumental) | extra4 = ひとり[instrumental] | length4 = 5:53 }} {{-}} ==="Kuroi Uta"=== {{Infobox song | name = Kuroi Uta | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Eir Aoi]] | album = Sirius | released = November 13, 2013 | format = [[CD single]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = 6:20 (single ver.) | label = [[Sony Music Entertainment Japan]] | writer = Keiichi Okabe, Kikuchi Hana | producer = | prev_title = Cobalt Sky | prev_year = 2013 | next_title = Niji no Oto | next_year = 2004 }} {{nihongo|"Kuroi Uta"|クロイウタ|Black Song}} is one of the two theme songs for ''Drakengard 3''. It was sung by [[Eir Aoi]], composed by ''Drakengard 3'' composer Keichi Okabe and written by Kikuchi Hana, one of the original scenario writers for ''Nier''.{{cite web|url=http://www.famitsu.com/news/201307/29037326.html|script-title=ja:音楽にも『ドラッグ オン ドラグーン』らしい仕掛けが!?　『DoD3』インタビュー|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2013-07-29|accessdate=2014-09-14}}{{cite web|url=http://vgmdb.net/album/42649|title=Kuroi Uta / Eir Aoi|publisher=VGMdb|accessdate=2014-09-24}} Aoi, a singer native to [[Hokkaido]], was chosen by Okabe to perform the song due to her outspoken admiration of the ''Drakengard'' series.{{cite web|url=http://dengekionline.com/elem/000/000/663/663480/|script-title=ja:ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3』藍井エイルさんインタビュー。藍井さんはアンヘルたんに過剰反応するガチファンだった【電撃DOD3】|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works|Dengeki Online]]|date=2013-07-16|accessdate=2014-09-14}}{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconera.com/2013/07/01/drakengard-3s-first-trailer-shows-off-gory-gameplay-footage/|title=Drakengard 3's First Trailer Shows Off Gory Gameplay Footage|author=Ishaan|publisher=Siliconera|date=2013-07-01|accessdate=2013-09-10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131229140758/http://www.siliconera.com/2013/07/01/drakengard-3s-first-trailer-shows-off-gory-gameplay-footage|archivedate=2013-12-29|deadurl=no}} Eir Aoi's fifth single, "Kuroi Uta" was originally released on November 13, 2013 as the final track on the single disc "Sirius".{{cite web|url=http://ex.famitsu.com/dod3/2013/11/13/32/|script-title=ja:藍井エイルが歌う『ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3』のテーマソング『クロイウタ』が収録された5th Single『シリウス』は本日発売|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2013-11-13|accessdate=2014-09-14}} The single reached #21 in the Oricon charts and remained in the charts for fourteen weeks.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/545902/products/music/1040456/1/|script-title=ja:藍井エイル - クロイウタ|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Oricon]]|accessdate=2014-09-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207132212/http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/545902/products/music/1040456/1/|archivedate=2013-12-07|deadurl=no}} {{Track listing | headline = Track list | collapsed = no | extra_column = Japanese title | title1 = Sirius | extra1 = シリウス[single version] | length1 = 4:28 | title2 = Addicted... | extra2 = | length2 = 3:32 | title3 = Kuroi Uta | extra3 = クロイウタ | length3 = 6:23 | title4 = Sirus (instrumental) | extra4 = シリウス[instrumental] | length4 = 4:24 }} {{-}} ==="This Silence is Mine"=== {{Infobox song | name = This Silence is Mine | cover = | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Onitsuka Chihiro]] | album = | released = December 18, 2013 | format = [[CD single]] | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = 7:06 | label = NAPOLEON RECORDS | writer = Keiichi Okabe, Onitsuka Chihiro | producer = Square Enix | prev_title = Itazura Pierrot | prev_year = 2013 | next_title = Anata to Science | next_year = 2013 }} "This Silence Is Mine", the game's second theme song, was specially written and sung by [[Onitsuka Chihiro]]. It was composed by Okabe. Okabe asked Chihiro to help with the song because he felt she would be the perfect singer to project the world and themes of ''Drakengard 3''. The intention was to make the song emotionally intense, but at the same time "cold" and "empty". While writing the song, Chihiro was inspired by Zero's presentation within the game. The original draft of the song was created in around five minutes, and Chihiro had to sing the song five times before Okabe was satisfied with her performance.{{cite web|url=http://dengekionline.com/elem/000/000/741/741531/|script-title=ja:ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3』鬼束ちひろさんインタビュー。歌詞や曲に込めた想い＆『ニーア』の岡部さんと作る新たな世界とは？【電撃DOD3】|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works|Dengeki Online]]|date=2013-09-24|accessdate=2014-09-24}} The song debuted in the game's trailer at the 2013 [[Tokyo Game Show]].{{cite web|url=http://dengekionline.com/elem/000/000/719/719038/|script-title=ja:『ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3』テーマ曲『This Silence Is Mine』は鬼束ちひろさんが担当。最新PVは血まみれのファイブなど意味深な場面が連続|trans-title=Onitsuka Chihiro is in charge of "Drag-On Dragoon 3" theme song "This Silence Is Mine". Latest PV contains profound scenes such as a blood-covered Five|language=Japanese|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works|Dengeki Online]]|date=2013-09-24|accessdate=2013-12-10}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zc8spvYg1Ik|title=ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3: TGS PV|author=[[Square Enix|Square Enix Japan]]|publisher=[[YouTube]]|date=2013-09-23|accessdate=2013-09-20}} The single was released on a CD along with a version of her following single {{nihongo|"Anata to Science"|あなたとSciencE|You and Science}}.{{cite web|url=http://ex.famitsu.com/dod3/2013/12/18/80/|script-title=ja:鬼束ちひろが歌う『ドラッグ オン ドラグーン3』のテーマソング『This Silence Is Mine』は本日12月18日発売|language=Japanese|publisher=''[[Famitsu]]''|date=2013-12-08|accessdate=2014-09-14}} The single reached 36th place in the Oricon charts.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/199687/products/music/1047821/1/|script-title=ja:鬼束ちひろ - This Silence Is Mine|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Oricon]]|accessdate=2014-09-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140117124940/http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/199687/products/music/1047821/1/|archivedate=2014-01-17|deadurl=no}} Huynh was positive about the song in his review of the soundtrack, saying that Chihiro "[brought] her best, delivering an emotional track with a powerful buildup to a dizzying climax." Gann was also positive, saying Chihiro's singing style fitted the tone of both game and series, calling the delivery "superb". He also called Okabe's production of the song "very smart". {{Track listing | headline = Track list | collapsed = no | extra_column = Japanese title | title1 = This Silence is Mine | extra1 = | length1 = 7:06 | title2 = Anata to SciencE ~hysteric version~ | extra2 = あなたとSciencE ~hysteric version~ | length2 = 3:51 }} {{-}} ==See also== *[[Music of Nier|Music of ''Nier'']] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Drakengard|state=expanded}} [[Category:Drakengard]] [[Category:Music by media franchise|Drakengard]] [[Category:Video game music discographies|Drakengard]] [[Category:Video game soundtracks|Drakengard]]

revision.comment: The production country is US, you can't expect them to be AUD, CAD, HKD...

Evans * Trevor Macy * [[Jason Blum]] }} | writer = {{plainlist| * Mike Flanagan * Jeff Howard }} | based on = {{based on|''Oculus: Chapter 3 – The Man with the Plan''|Mike Flanagan}} | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Karen Gillan]] * [[Brenton Thwaites]] * [[Rory Cochrane]] * [[Katee Sackhoff]] }} | music = The Newton Brothers | cinematography = [[Michael Fimognari]] | editing = Mike Flanagan | studio = {{plainlist| * [[Blumhouse Productions]] * [[WWE Studios]] * MICA Entertainment * [[Intrepid Pictures]] }} | distributor = [[Relativity Media]] | released = {{Film date|2013|09|08|[[2013 Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|2014|04|11|United States}} | runtime = 103 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 103:16--><ref>{{cite web|title=''OCULUS'' (15)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/oculus-film|work=[[Warner Bros.]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=May 2, 2014|accessdate=May 2, 2014}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $5 million<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-can-captain-america-coast-over-rio-2-20140409,0,3427483.story The Los Angeles Times]</ref> | gross = $44 million<ref name="Oculus 2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=oculus.htm|title=Oculus (2014)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref> }}
'''''Oculus''''' is a 2013 American [[supernatural horror film]] written, edited, and directed by [[Mike Flanagan (director)|Mike Flanagan]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hot Trailer: ‘Oculus’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/03/hot-trailer-oculus/|accessdate=6 March 2014|newspaper=deadline.com|date=5 March 2014}}</ref> It is based on his [[short film]] ''Oculus: Chapter 3 – The Man with the Plan'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Scares come in pairs in horror movie ‘Oculus’|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2014/04/09/4830606/scares-come-in-pairs-in-horror.html#.U0e16VVdXA0|publisher=Charlotte Observer|accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref> and stars [[Karen Gillan]] as a young woman who is convinced that an antique mirror is responsible for the death and misfortune that her family suffered.
The film had its world premiere on September 5, 2013, at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]] (TIFF) and received a [[Wide release|wide theatrical release]] on April 11, 2014.<ref>[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/wwe-studios-relativity-and-blumhouse-productions-partner-on-intrepid-pictures-oculus-2014-01-18 WWE® Studios, Relativity and Blumhouse Productions Partner on Intrepid Pictures' ''Oculus'']. Marketwatch.com.</ref> It received generally positive reviews from critics,<ref name="MC" /> and was a box office success.<ref name="Oculus 2014" />
==Plot== The film takes place in two different times: the present and 11 years earlier. The two plot lines are told in parallel through [[Flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]]. In 2002, software engineer Alan Russell moves into a new house with his wife Marie, 10-year-old son Tim, and 12-year-old daughter Kaylie. Alan purchases an antique mirror to decorate his office. Unbeknownst to them, the mirror supernaturally induces hallucinations. Marie is haunted by visions of her own body decaying, while Alan is seduced by a ghostly woman named Marisol, who has mirrors in place of eyes.
Over time, the parents become psychotic; Alan isolates himself in his office, and Marie becomes withdrawn and paranoid. All of the plants in the house die, and the family dog disappears after being shut in the office with the mirror. After Kaylie sees Alan with Marisol, she tells her mother, and the parents fight. One night, Marie goes insane and attempts to kill her children, but Alan locks her away. When the family runs out of food, the children realize that their father is under the influence of the mirror, so Kaylie goes to seek help from their mother, and finds her chained to the wall, acting like an animal. Kaylie and Tim try going to their neighbors for help, but the neighbors disbelieve their stories. When Kaylie attempts to use the phone, she discovers that all of her phone calls are answered by the same man.
One night, Alan unchains Marie, and both parents attack the children. Marie briefly comes to her senses, only to be shot dead by Alan. The children try to destroy the mirror but it tricks them, making them believe they are hitting the mirror when they are actually hitting the wall. Alan also experiences a moment of lucidity and kills himself by forcing Tim to pull the trigger of the gun and shoot him. Before dying, he begs the children to run, but Marisol and other victims of the mirror appear as horrific ghosts. The police arrive and take Tim into custody. Before the siblings are separated, they promise to reunite as adults and destroy the mirror. As Tim is taken away, he sees the ghosts of his parents watching him from the house.
Eleven years later, Tim is discharged from a psychiatric hospital, having come to believe that there were no supernatural events involved in his parents' deaths. Kaylie has spent most of her young adulthood researching the history of the mirror. Using her position as an employee of an auction house, she obtains access to the mirror and has it transported to the family home, where she places it in a room filled with surveillance cameras and a "kill switch" — an anchor weighted to the ceiling. Kaylie intends to destroy the mirror, but first wants to document its powers, proving Tim's innocence.
Tim attempts to convince Kaylie that she's wrong and the siblings argue. When they notice the houseplants begin to wilt, they review the camera footage and see themselves performing actions they have no memory of. Tim finally accepts that the mirror has an evil power and attempts to escape the house with Kaylie, only for the pair to be drawn back by the mirror's influence. Seeing a hallucination of her mother, Kaylie stabs it in the neck, only to realize that she has stabbed her fiancé. They try to call the police, but are only able to reach the same voice who spoke to them on the phone as children. Tim activates the kill switch, realizing too late that Kaylie stood in its path, and he has killed her. The police arrive and arrest Tim, who is hysterical, just as they did when he was younger. As both a boy and an adult, Tim claims the mirror is responsible. As he is taken away, Tim's adult incarnation sees Kaylie's ghost standing in the house with his parents.
==Cast== * [[Karen Gillan]] as Kaylie Russell ** [[Annalise Basso]] as 12-year-old Kaylie Russell * [[Brenton Thwaites]] as Tim Russell ** Garrett Ryan Ewald as 10-year-old Tim Russell * [[Katee Sackhoff]] as Marie Russell * [[Rory Cochrane]] as Alan Russell * [[James Lafferty]] as Michael Dumont * [[Miguel Sandoval]] as Dr. Graham * [[Kate Siegel]] as Marisol Chavez
==Production== The film is based on Flanagan's earlier 2005 short horror film, also called ''Oculus''. The short contained only one setting, a single actor, and a mirror.<ref name=moviesonline.ca>{{cite web|title=Director Mike Flanagan Interview,Oculus|url=http://www.moviesonline.ca/2014/04/director-mike-flanagan-interview-oculus/|website=moviesonline.ca|accessdate=Aug 6, 2014}}</ref> The short became highly acclaimed, and interest quickly arose regarding the adaptation of the short into a feature.<ref name=moviesonline.ca/> Initially, studios were interested in making the film in accordance with the [[Found footage (pseudo-documentary)|found footage]] genre;<ref name=Denofgeek>{{cite web|last1=Kaye|first1=Don|title=Interview: Oculus director Mike Flanagan|url=http://www.denofgeek.us/movies/oculus/234666/interview-oculus-director-mike-flanagan|website=Den of Geek|accessdate=August 9, 2014}}</ref> however, Flanagan was opposed to this and passed on such offers.<ref name=Denofgeek/> Eventually, Intrepid Pictures expressed interest in producing the film "as long as you don't do it found footage".
Expanding the premise to a feature-length screenplay proved challenging, as Flanagan felt like he had "pushed the limit" of what could be done with the premise in the short. The solution Flanagan came across was to combine two storylines, past and present, intercut with one another. The idea was to "create a sense of distortion and disorientation that would be similar for the viewer as it was for Tim and Kaylie in the room."<ref name=moviesonline.ca/> In early drafts, it was difficult to distinguish between the two timelines, until the team hit upon the idea of writing all of the scenes from the past in [[italics]].<ref name=moviesonline.ca/>
Inspired by the stories of [[H. P. Lovecraft]], Flanagan chose to not explain the mirror's origins, describing to Den of Geek that he liked how [[Lovecraftian horror|Lovecraftian]] literature often seemed to be an "alien force that if you even were to try to comprehend it completely it would drive you mad."<ref name=Denofgeek/> He expanded: "Evil in the world doesn't have an answer."<ref name=Denofgeek/>
On October 27, 2012, filming wrapped in [[Fairhope, Alabama]], after three weeks.<ref>{{cite web |title={{-'}}Oculus', starring Katee Sackhoff & Karen Gillan, filming underway in Alabama |url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2012/10/24/oculus-starring-katee-sackhoff-karen-gillan-filming-underway-in-alabama/ |accessdate=17 February 2014 |publisher=On Location Vacations |date=24 October 2012}}</ref>
==Release== The film was first released on September 5, 2013, at the 2013 TIFF,<ref>{{cite web|author1=Matt Barone|title=TIFF Review: The Smart, Inventive "Oculus" Is the Best Horror Film of the Festival|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2013/09/oculus-movie-review|website=Complex|publisher=Complex Media, Inc|accessdate=31 October 2014|date=10 September 2013}}</ref> and received a worldwide theatrical release on April 11, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=UPDATE: New 'Oculus' theatrical poster debuts|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/overtheropes/wwestudios/oculus-theatrical-poster-debuts-26176636|website=WWE|publisher=WWE Inc|accessdate=31 October 2014|date=10 March 2014}}</ref>
The film was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc]] on August 5, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Derek Anderson|title=Oculus Blu-ray & DVD Release Details and Cover Art|url=http://dailydead.com/oculus-blu-ray-dvd-release-details/|website=Daily Dead|publisher=DailyDead.com|accessdate=31 October 2014|date=20 June 2014}}</ref>
==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = Oculus | type = soundtrack | artist = The Newton Brothers | cover = | alt = | released = April 15, 2014 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Classical, stage and screen | length = 1:11:13 | label = [[Varèse Sarabande]] | producer = Bryon Davis | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The soundtrack to ''Oculus'' was released [[Digital distribution|digitally]] on April 8, 2014 and on [[Compact Disc|CD]] on April 15, 2014.<ref>[http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/03/25/oculus-soundtrack-details/ Oculus Soundtrack] Film Music Reporter. Retrieved 24 July 2014</ref>
{{Track listing | collapsed = yes | total_length = 71:13<ref>[http://www.allmusic.com/album/oculus-mw0002626517 Oculus Soundtrack] AllMusic. Retrieved 24 July 2014</ref> | title1 = Recurring Dream | length1 = 1:34 | title2 = The Auction | length2 = 3:20 | title3 = Moving IN | length3 = 1:47 | title4 = You Promised Me | length4 = 1:20 | title5 = Juice Box | length5 = 0:33 | title6 = Kaylie's Nightmare | length6 = 0:57 | title7 = Graphic Photos | length7 = 1:48 | title8 = The Mirror | length8 = 1:02 | title9 = Grotesque Cow | length9 = 0:16 | title10 = The Other Woman | length10 = 0:16 | title11 = Memories Surface | length11 = 1:14 | title12 = Dead Plants | length12 = 0:47 | title13 = We Have a Gun to Its Head | length13 = 1:41 | title14 = History of the Mirror | length14 = 1:55 | title15 = Fuzzy-Trace Theory | length15 = 2:30 | title16 = Mason Was Sick | length16 = 0:27 | title17 = Fingernails | length17 = 1:41 | title18 = Book Stacking | length18 = 1:14 | title19 = Whispers in the Glass | length19 = 0:19 | title20 = Who Are You Talking To? | length20 = 1:04 | title21 = The Reveal | length21 = 2:55 | title22 = Marisol, Marisol, Marisol | length22 = 2:53 | title23 = Shifting Glass | length23 = 0:48 | title24 = Marie's Breakdown | length24 = 3:40 | title25 = Lightbulbs & Apples | length25 = 2:30 | title26 = Seeing Things | length26 = 0:57 | title27 = Broken Plates | length27 = 0:58 | title28 = She Needs a Doctor | length28 = 1:20 | title29 = This Isn't Real | length29 = 4:59 | title30 = Staring Eyes | length30 = 5:12 | title31 = It Won't Let Us | length31 = 0:56 | title32 = I've Seen the Devil and He Is ME | length32 = 2:54 | title33 = A Mother's Embrace | length33 = 3:17 | title34 = Oculus | length34 = 4:41 | title35 = Oculus | note35 = Remix) (featuring [[Paul Oakenfold]] | length35 = 2:49 | title36 = Oculus of Glass | note36 = featuring Paul Oakenfold | length36 = 4:39 }}
==Reception== ===Critical reception=== {{expand section|date=July 2016}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 74% based on 144 reviews with an average rating of 6.5/10. The site’s critical consensus reads, "With an emphasis on dread over gore and an ending that leaves the door wide open for sequels, ''Oculus'' could be just the first spine-tingling chapter in a new franchise for discerning horror fans."<ref>{{cite web|title=Oculus|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/oculus/|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=October 31, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 61 out of 100 based on 28 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/oculus |title=Oculus |website=Metacritic}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "C" on an A+ to F scale.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
[[Shock Till You Drop]] gave ''Oculus'' a positive review, stating that it was "smart and scary stuff".<ref>{{cite web|title=SXSW Review: Ambition, Originality & Scares Drive Oculus|url=http://www.shocktillyoudrop.com/news/349261-sxsw-review-ambition-originality-scares-drive-oculus/|publisher=STYD|accessdate=10 March 2014}}</ref> [[Film School Rejects]] gave a mixed review and stated that it was "well-acted, looks quite good, and manages some moments of entertainment, but as the minutes tick by it grows weaker and weaker until its final cheat is designed to allow for a shocker ending."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hunter|first=Rob|title=SXSW 2014 Review: ‘Oculus’ Is Horror Reduced by a Slimming Mirror|url=http://filmschoolrejects.com/reviews/oculus.php|publisher=Film School Rejects|accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref>
===Box office=== Released in the United States on April 11, 2014, ''Oculus'' grossed $4,966,899 on its opening day, nearly equaling its production budget of $5 million. As of October 3, 2014, the film has taken in an estimated $27,695,246 at the North American box office and another $16,335,000 internationally for a worldwide total of $44,030,246.<ref name="Oculus 2014"/>
==Legacy== ===Remake=== In March 2015, [[Relativity Media]], B4U Television Network, and [[Balaji Telefilms]] confirmed a [[Bollywood]] remake with the title ''Zahhak''. The title was later changed to ''[[Dobaara: See Your Evil]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/94531/oculus-gets-a-bollywood-makeover/|title=Oculus Gets a Bollywood Makeover|publisher=[[Dread Central]]|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref> This film is directed by [[Prawaal Raman]] and stars [[Huma Qureshi (actress)|Huma Qureshi]] and [[Saqib Saleem]] in the leading roles. Director [[Mike Flanagan (director)|Mike Flanagan]] served as the executive producer. The film was released on June 2, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/relativity-media-reveals-slate-of-remakes-in-india-1201459724/|title=Relativity Media Reveals Slate of Remakes in India|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of ghost films]]

revision.text:
'''Raise the Roof''' is a Broadway producing entity. It is composed of the producers [[Harriet Leve]], Jennifer Isaacson, and the members of [[WalkRunFly Productions]]: [[Brandon Victor Dixon]] and Warren Adams.
The group was founded by Jean Doumanian, Elaine Krauss, [[Harriet Leve]], and Jennifer Isaacson. Their first venture together was ''Burn the Floor'' as Raise the Roof 1. Next, Krauss, Leve, and Manocherian came together as Raise the Roof 2 to produce the recent Broadway production of ''[[Superior Donuts]]'' by [[Tracy Letts]], the [[Pulitzer Prize]] winning playwright of ''[[August: Osage County]]''. Doumanian was a lead producer on that production. In 2010, the group, as Raise the Roof 3, produced the Tony nominee for Best Revival, ''[[A Little Night Music]]'', starring [[Catherine Zeta Jones]] (who won a Tony for this performance) and [[Angela Lansbury]] (who was nominated for a Tony for this performance). On July 13, 2010, Broadway legends [[Bernadette Peters]] and [[Elaine Stritch]] joined the cast and assumed those roles. They were also represented, as Raise the Roof 4, by the Tony Award winning Best Revival of ''[[La Cage aux Folles (musical)|La Cage Aux Folles]]'', starring [[Kelsey Grammer]] (who was nominated for a Tony for this performance) and [[Douglas Hodge]] (who won a Tony for this performance).
==Productions==
'''[[La Cage aux Folles (musical)|La Cage Aux Folles]]''' [Revival, Musical] <ref name="La Cage">[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=484929 La Cage Aux Folles on IBDB]</ref> : Cast featuring: [[Kelsey Grammer]], [[Douglas Hodge]], A.J. Shively : April 6, 2010 - Present
'''[[A Little Night Music]]''' [Revival, Musical] <ref name="A Little Night Music">[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=485016 A Little Night Music on IBDB]</ref> : Cast featuring: [[Catherine Zeta-Jones]] (through June 20th), [[Angela Lansbury]] (through June 20th), [[Bernadette Peters]] (beginning July 13th), [[Elaine Stritch]] (beginning July 13th), [[Alexander Hanson (actor)|Alexander Hanson]], [[Erin Davie]], Hunter Ryan Herdlicka, [[Leigh Ann Larkin]], [[Aaron Lazar]], Ramona Mallory : November 24, 2009–Present
'''[[Superior Donuts]]''' [Original, Play] <ref name="Superior Donuts">[http://ibdb.com/production.php?id=484305 Superior Donuts on IBDB]</ref> : Cast featuring: [[Michael McKean]], [[Jon Michael Hill]], Yasen Peyankov, James Vincent Meredith, Kate Buddeke, Robert Maffia, Jane Alderman, Cliff Chamberlain, Michael Garvey : September 16, 2009 - January 3, 2010
'''Burn the Floor''' [Dance] <ref name="Burn the Floor">[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=484014 Burn The Floor on IBDB]</ref> : Created by Harley Medcalf : Featuring: [[Maksim Chmerkovskiy]], [[Karina Smirnoff]], Henry Bayalikov, [[Sharna Burgess]], [[Kevin Clifton]], Sasha Farber, Jeremy Garner, [[Anya Garnis]], Gordana Grandosek, Patrick Helm, Sarah Hives, Melanie Hooper, [[Peta Murgatroyd]], Giselle Peacock, Sarah Soriano, Damon Sugden, Rebecca Sugden, Damian Whitewood, Trent Widdon, and Robin Windsor : July 25, 2009 – January 10, 2010
